In mEd 5:6, R. Judah mentions him, seeIntroduction 7.5.1.2-3.

Should probably be identified with ̓Ανάνηλος of Babylonia, mentioned in Josephus (see under Hananel no. 1), because rabbinic literature mentions the latter as an officiating high priest, and the assumption is that Josephus presents us with the complete list of Second Temple officiating high priests. The origin (Egyptian rather than Babylonian) may be a rabbinic distortion, based perhaps on a confusion between this priest and Σίμων υἱὸς Βοηθοῦ (Simon no. 24), the high priest who followed ̓Ανάνηλος, who, according to Josephus, came from Egypt. The name חנמאל is probably Egyptian (Ranke, ÄPN 2, 268, no. 30). If there is no confusion, we could assume that rabbinic literature is refering to one of the persons occaisionally designated “high priest” without actually being one, see Introduction 3.2.5.
He is designated המצרי in rabbinic literature. See Introduction 6.3.1.
Associated with the Temple service, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.

So in Josephus. I assume this is his transliteration of חנן, the name of this priestly family recorded in rabbinic literature as בית חנן. LXX has ̔Ανάν (H & R Suppl. 17). On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1.

So in NT. This is another idiosyncratic NT orthography. On the abbrevaition of biblical names in the transliteration process, see Introduction 2.1.3. This form is not found in Josephus (Schalit, NB, 11. There the form ̓Αννάς is used for an Egyptian Pharaoh, but it is only one variant of the name) or in LXX, except in the apocryphal books, for which we have no way of knowing what biblical name it is transliterating (H & R Suppl. 18). However, the person thus transliterated in NT is clearly identical with ̓́Ανανοςof Josephus (Stern, “Aspects of Jewish Society,” 607).

In AJ 20:198 Josephus relates the fact that this person had five sons who were all nominated to the high priesthood. However, in his writings, he only identifies ̓́Ανανος (Hanan no. 4) and ̓Ιωνάθης (Jonathan no. 7) as his sons. Another two were, apparently, Θεοφίλος, who in AJ 18:123 is described as ̓Ιωνάθης’s brother (Theophilos no. 3 G/M) and Ματθίας who is described as such in AJ 19:316 (Mattathias no. 11). If we assume that Josephus’ list of high priests is more or less complete, we must assume that the fifth son was a certain ̓Ελεάζαρος τὸν ̓Ανάνου, mentioned in AJ 18:34 (Eleazar no. 21), even though Josephus himself does not hint at this. This proliferation of high priests led to the father’s name becoming a famous family name (bPes 57a and Stern, “Aspects of Jewish Society,” 607).
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

BT (bBer22a) mentions a tana called נתן בן אבישלום, but in the ms. tradition the name is אלעזר בן שמוע, so presumably there is no such person. I mention him here because חנן בן אבישלום is the closest name.
Described here as a judge (מדיני גזרות) in Jerusalem, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
This is probably an Aramicized form of חנן (Zunz, Namen, 22). See also Introduction 2.4.3.2.

Most of his traditions, including this one, refer to the Temple. In bPes 57a he criticizes the High Priestly houses. In the Tosefta (tMen13:21) this tradition is associated with יוסי בן יוחנן איש ירושלים (Joseph no. 45), but see Lieberman, TR 2, 265. See Introduction 7.5.1.1.
In PT (yKil 2:6 28a) he is designated thus.

In this tradition he is described as a contemporary of Eliezer, R. Simon’s son, see Introduction 7.5.1.3-4.
This is the only tradition in which he is mentioned and the chronological context is not quite clear, although he could be construed as a contemporary of R. Aqiba, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.

See Introduction 6.2. The fictitious character of this ancient figure is obvious because, on the one hand, he is only mentioned in BT, and on the other hand, he is mentioned in a literary context of mythical rainmakers. Making him a relation of חוני המעגל, the famous rainmaker, would be a typical literary strategy of BT (Safrai, “Tales of the Sages”).
No identifiable rabbi is mentioned in his vicinity, but a calculation of how old can the grandson of a man who lived ca. 65 BCE still places him prior to 70 CE.

See Introduction 6.3.1.

According to bKet 105a, he was a judge in Jerusalem together with חנן בן אבשלום and אדמון בן גידאי. In bSah 17b, however, he is associated in a list of names with שמעון בן זומא (Simon no. 64), שמעון בן עזאי (Simon no. 57) and חנינא בן חכינאי (Hananiah no. 18), who are of the generation of R. Aqiba. See Introduction 7.5.2.

On this text see Lieberman, Greek, 182. He identifies this חנין with ̓Ανανία τω͂ τοῦ Νεδεβαίου, (Hananiah no. 2) massacred by the Sicarii in 66 CE. If, however, this identification is rejected, than one has to contend that his person is fictitious because of the late date of the midrash in which he appears, see Introduction 6.2.3.
The tradition in which he is mentioned describes an event that took place in Jerusalem during the revolt against Rome.

This form is also found in the Bible, e.g. 2 Sam 10:1 (name of the king of the Ammonites). However, it is doubtful whether in Second Temple times the name was viewed as altogether different from חנין. Furthermore, in epigraphic sources, the letters ו and י are hardly distinguishable. See also Introduction 2.4.3.2.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

The name was found on an ossuary in a cave with many Latin names (e.g. ̓Αφρεικανός). Abel RB 10 (1913) 274, who first published the finds suggested that this was the Latin name Anius. However, just as̔́̔̀Αννας is traditionally understood as חנן, so too ̔́̔̀Ανιςcould be interpreted as חנין. For the single ν see Introduction 2.3.4. The form is recorded in ancient Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 32).
See Introduction 6.3.1.1.

See above, n. 45. This form is also found in the Bible, e.g. 2 Sam 10:1 (name of the king of the Ammonites). However, it is doubtful whether in Second Temple times the name was viewed as altogether different from חנין. Furthermore, in epigraphic sources, the letters ו and י are hardly distinguishable. See also Introduction 2.4.3.2.

person.note: On dating of the Masada documents see Introduction 7.8.
חננאל is transliterated in LXX as ̔Ανανιήλ (H & R Suppl. 17). This is Josephus’ declined version. On Josephus and LXX transliterations, see Introduction 2.1.1.1.

Should probably be identified with חנמאל המצרי (see Hanamel no. 1), because rabbinic literature mentions the latter as an officiating high priest, and the assumption is that Josephus presents us with the complete list of Second Temple officiating high priests. The origin (Egyptian rather than Babylonian) may be a rabbinic distortion, based perhaps on a confusion between this priest and Σίμων υἱὸς Βοηθοῦ, (Simon no. 24) the high priest who followed ̓Ανάνηλος, who, according to Josephus, came from Egypt.
Josephus, ad loc. claims this priest came from Babylonia. See Introduction 6.3.1.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
This is the spelling both in LXX (H & R Suppl. 17) and in Josephus (Schalit, NB, 11).
So according to Epiphanius, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 143), see Introduction 2.8.3. On the interchange of ה and א see Introduction 2.4.2.7.
On Arist see Introduction 6.2.1, and Cohen, JSJ 15 (1984) 53. The name is recorded elsewhere in Egyptian antiquity (Preisigke, NB, 29).
For dating of Arist see Introduction 7.1.1.
So in Josephus and NT, see above, n. 2. This is the spelling both in LXX (H & R Suppl. 17) and in Josephus (Schalit, NB, 11).

So in rabbinic literature. On the assumption that Josephus’ list of officiating high priests is a closed one, and on the assumption that נדבאי rather than נרבאי is the correct reading, יוחנן בן נדבאי mentioned in BT (bPes. 57a) in the famous dirge against Second Temple priests should be identified with ̓Ανανία τω͂ τοῦ Νεδεβαίου mentioned in Josephus. Although the names חנניה and יוחנן are anagrams one of the other, and mean virtually the same in Hebrew (=Yahweh has graced), the two cannot be assumed to be the same name, and a mistake was made by one of the sources (obviously rabbinic literature).
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. This is the spelling both in LXX (H & R Suppl. 17) and in Josephus (Schalit, NB, 11).

person.note: The decision to separate this person from the previous is a random one. ̓Ανανίας the father of ̓Ελεάζαρος στρατηγός of the Temple, also fashioned “son of the High Priest (τοῦ ἀρχιερέως νεανίας -BJ 2:409)” would suggest the identification of the two. However, Josephus himself does not make this point too clearly and is rather loose in his use of the title “high priest,” and see above, under Eleazar no. 11. On the problems arising from the identification of these persons, see Ilan & Price, JQR 84 (1993) 203, n. 58. And see also, above, under Eleazar, no. 61.

חנינא, sometimes with a final ה and sometimes with a final א (see Introduction 2.4.2.3) is an Aramicized variant of the name חנניה (see Introduction 2.4.2.6). That it was intermittently used could be amply demonstrated by consulting Kosovsky’s name concordance for PT, e.g. חנינא/חנניה בן עקביה (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 276), where the two forms are consistantly confused.

In the tannaitic literature there is no chronological indiction for חנינא בן דוסא. However, both PT (e.g. yBer5:6, 9d) and BT (bBer 34b) agree that he was of the generation of Rabban Gamliel at Yabneh, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

In the Mishnah here, he is described as bringing a ruling from prison, which is usually interpreted as coming from R. Aqiba, who was the most famous prisoner, but the text does not mention the captive sage. In tSan 2:13, however, he is clearly mentioned as a contemporary of Rabban Gamaliel, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

Tannaitic literature is not clear on a chronological marker for this sage. However, both PT (yNed 6:13, 40a) and BT (bBer 63a) agree that he was active after the Bar Kokhba Revolt. If he was R. Joshua’s nephew, this fits chronologically, see Introduction 7.5.1.3.

The way this name is written, with a final ן in the middle of the word, suggests either that the scribe understood this name as comprised of two separate words (as it actually is) or that the final letters were not yet completely fixed, see Introduction 2.7.5. This person’s name is repeatedly written with the final ן in a medial position in all the documents in which he signs his name, indicating that he knew the difference between the two letters and chose to write it thus.

For a possible identification of this חנניה with ̓Ανανία τω͂ τοῦ Νεδεβαίου(Hananiah no. 2), the High Priest, see M. Wise, Thunder in Gemini and Other Essays on the History, Language and Literature of Second Temple Palestine(Sheffield 1994) 51-100. The identification is uncertain, particularly since so little of the high priest’s name was preserved on this sherd. One should keep in mind that persons belonging to high priestly families also fashioned themselves “high priests”, see Introduction 3.2.5. And see also Eshel, Zion 64 (1999) 501-2and Introduction 3.3.

person.note: This is how Josephus and LXX transliterate the biblical חצרון (Schalit, NB, 46; H & R Suppl. 62).
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

This is the suggested reading of the editor. This transliteration of the name is unknown. There is only one other case in this corpus where ζ transliterates צ, see Σαλαμηζίνω for שלמציון (Shelamzion no. 22 S-H/F). Alternatively, this may be an elaborate form of the name עזרא (DJD 2, 217).
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
On this variant form see Introduction 2.6.2.

This could also be construed as a nickname, since it means “smith” and was a popular and important occupation at the time (and is probably also the origin of the biblical name. And note also the wide distribution of the name “Smith” among English-speaking people, and Schmidt among the Germans). Stark, PNPI, 90, however, derives the name from “deaf”. See also Introduction 6.1.1. And see also under נפח (Napah – S-H/M).
According to Mekh. dRI 228, he is a contemporary of R. Eliezer Haqapar (Eleazar no. 46), see under him, and see Introduction 7.5.1.4.
In Hebrew – איש גינוסר.

In LXX the form ̔Ασούβis used for חשוב (H & R Suppl. 24). It appears twice on the ossuary in the genitive. However, note the nominative form on this ossuary (Ασους), without the β, repeated five times. Ασους is not a recorded Greek name. It is recorded once on a Papyrus from Egypt (Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 58).
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.bibl: 2 Macc 3:11 (H & R Suppl. 151); BJ 1:31; AJ 12:160 (Schalit, NB, 120); CPJnos. 4, 5.
person.note: Thus in Josephus and 2 Macc. LXX has this transliteration, next to Τωβειά, Τωβιά, Τωβείας, Τώβεις andΤωβίς (H & R Suppl. 151).
This is the orthography of the Zenon Papyri, see Introduction 2.3.3.1.

On the name Tobias as a personal and family name, and on the identification of the man mentioned in the Zenon Papyri with the man mentioned in Josephus (both of Transjordan), see B. Mazar, “The Tobiads,” IEJ 7 (1957) 137-45, 229-38. For the suggestion that he is of this family, but perhaps the grandfather of the Tobias mentioned by Josephus, see D. R. Schwartz, “Josephus’ Tobiads: Back to the Second Century?” in M. Goodman (ed.), Jews in a Graeco-Roman World (Oxford 1998) 47-61 (particularly 59-60).
On the independent character of 2 Macc see Introduction 5.1.2.
On dating in 2 Macc see Introduction 7.1.3.

See above, n. 13. On this variation of the name see Introduction 2.4.1.1. This is probably the same name (see Introduction 2.4.1.9), though the ו-suffix may be of Nabatean provenance, see Introduction 2.4.5.1. The name טובו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 500); טביו is recorded among Idumaeans (AOFCI, nos. 174, 183). Alternatively we can perhaps view here a letter displacement (for טובי), see Introduction 2.7.3, and see also Naveh, Mas I, 21.
See Introduction 3.2.7.

note.ref: See above, n. 22. On dating of the Masada documents see Introduction 7.8.

person.note: On dating the inscribed material from Gezer see Introduction 7.6.4.

Thus in Josephus. He transliterates the biblical יאיר as ̓Ιαείρης (Schalit, NB, 56). LXX transliterates him ̓Αείρ (H & R Suppl. 7), but elsewhere, another יאיר is transliterated ̓Ιάειρος, as here (H & R Suppl. 74). On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. The Hebrew ostracon from Masada has יאיר.

One of the most important finds in Masada, which allowed for the naive interpretation of the archaeological dig in light of Josephus’ description of the events (BJ 7:275-406), was this pot sherd, with the name בן יאיר on it (Yadin,Masada, 197-201). For a criticism of this position taken by Yadin, see S. J. D. Cohen, “Masada: Literary Tradition, Archaeological Remains and the Literary Credibility of Josephus,” JJS 33 (1982) 385-405. On the possibility that the reading here is בני אור (Sons of Light, as in Qumran) see Naveh, Mas I, 28-9. See also Introduction 3.3.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
This NT orthography complies with a LXX variant spelling (H & R Suppl. 74), see Introduction 2.1.1.2. For this Greek variation see Introduction 2.3.2.
In Greek – εἷς τῶν ἀρχισυναγώγων. I assume the author of Acta Pilati A: 1 took the Jewish dignitary ̓Ιάειρος, mentioned there to be the same as this one.
On dating according to NT see Introduction 7.3.
In tOhil 18:18 his son is portrayed as a contemporary of R. Judah the Patriarch, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.
Here Rabban Simon ben Gamaliel is transmitting in his name, see Introduction 7.5.1.2-3.

So are the declensions on the two ossuaries. See above, n. 2. Thus in Josephus. He transliterates the biblical יאיר as ̓Ιαείρης (Schalit, NB, 56). On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. The Hebrew ostracon from Masada has יאיר.

I assume this is the same person on each of the ossuaries because the two were found in the same burial chamber and, whereas on the one ossuary (1367) the buried individual is ̓Ιάειρος, son of ̓Ι[ω]άνου, on the other one (1368) ̓Ιαείρου is the father of ̓Ιώσηπος. One is his ossuary and one is his son’s.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: Claimed in one of the most important documents on the rabbinic chronology – the Letter of Sherira Gaon (A. Hyman, The Letter of R. Sherira Gaon[London 1910] 52 [Hebrew]). See also Introduction 6.3.1.

The assumption that this person is R. Ishmael’s disciple is not based on a tannaitic text that describes him as such, but on his continuos appearance in compositions associated with this school (e.g. Kosovsky, Mechilta, 15*-16*). Nevertheless, we have no clear chronological indicator for him, apart from his appearance in tannaitic literature, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.

person.note: This rebel became famous in 4 BCE with Herod’s death. His identification with Judah no. 10, who became famous in 6 CE has been tentatively suggested by e.g. M. Stern, “Zealots,” Encyclopedia Judaica Year Book(Jerusalem 1973) 136, and see also Ilan, Zion 51 (1986) 358-60. However, due to the popularity of the name Judah, and the silence of Josephus on this point, the suggestion must remain tentative, see Introduction 3.3.

Stern, “Zealots,” Encyclopedia Judaica Year Book(Jerusalem 1973) 136, and see also Ilan, Zion 51 (1986) 358-60. person.note: See above, n. 2. This is Josephus’ and 1 and 2 Macc’s spelling of this biblical name (Schalit, NB, 63), and it is also spelt thus occasionally in LXX (H & R Suppl. 86), although the form ̓Ιουδα is also recorded (ibid., 85). On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. In some mss the version here is ̓Ιούδης. Josephus transliterates the biblical אהוד in this way (Schalit, NB, 63), but since in all the following cases ̓Ιούδης is just a variant, one may assume that Josephus means the name יהודה, and a later scribe applied an unlikely transliteration to it. For the interchange of α and η, see Introduction 2.3.3.3.

I assume he is identical with ̓Ιούδην ̓Ιωνάθου mentioned in BJ 2:628, not because he is the same man, but because Josephus had made a mistake and used this person’s name inBJ2:628(Ilan & Price, JQR 84 [1993] 193-4; and already Schlatter, HN, 54-5).

person.note: So in Arabic, see Introduction 2.8.5. In Hebrew it would be יהודא. On this form see above, n. 3. So according to Epiphanius, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 142-3), see Introduction 2.8.3. On the interchange of ה and א see Introduction 2.4.2.7.

note.ref: See above, n. 75. All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, Introduction 6.2.2. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.

person.note: Figures in an event associated with Jesus’ early childhood.
On the problem of whether this famous R. Judah is indeed the son of ר' אלעי see under Eleazar no. 32.
He is R. Judah, see Introduction 7.5.1.3.

On the identity of this person (and on the fact that, despite seemingly chronological difficulties, there was only one person of this name), see A. Schremer, “Yehudah ben Batirah,” a paper delivered in the 12th World Congress of Jewish Studies, Jerusalem August 1997.
According to mNeg 9:3 and 11:7 he is a contemporary of R. Eliezer, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
In most of the traditions in which he is mentioned in the Mishnah (e.g. mAb 6:8), he is transmitting traditions in the name of R. Simon, see Introduction 7.5.1.3-4.

He is usually described as a contemporary of R. Aqiba in tannaitic literature. In amoraic literature he is described as a Bar Kokhba Revolt martyr, e.g. bSan 14a. Tannaitic literature also suggests this, albeit more subtly, see tSot 13:4. See Introduction 7.5.1.2.
In Hebrew – הכהן.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
He is one of the “pairs,” see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
In Hebrew – רבי יהודה הנשיא.
He is Rabbi, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.
In Hebrew – איש כפר הבבלי.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
In Hebrew, in the Tosefta – איש ברתותא. His provenance from Bartuta is not mentioned in the Mishnah, but it is mentioned in the parallel tradition in tZab 1:5.
According to tZab 1:5, his son is an older contemporary of R. Aqiba, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
In Hebrew – גר עמוני. The name Judah seems to have been particularly popular among proselytes in the Greco-Roman period (Ilan, SCI 11 [1991-2] 154-5).
Here he is a contemporary of R. Joshua and Rabban Gamaliel, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
In Hebrew – איש כפר עכו.

In tKil 1:12 a person by this name is mentioned. I assume that יהודה בן אגרא in tKet1:2 and tNid3:3 as well as יהודה איש כפר עכו mentioned as ר' שמעון’s father in tSot8:11, tBB 7:10; tSan13:12, tZeb 1:3 and tNeg 6:1 is the same.
Here Rabban Simon ben Gamaliel is transmitting in his name, see Introduction 7.5.1.2-3.
A certain יהודה בן דוסתאי is mentioned in BT, but he should be identified with this one. His saying in bMak 7a is a near parallel to the saying of דוסתאי בן יהודה in tSan 5:11.
In tHul8:19 he transmits a tradition in the name of R. Simon, see Introduction 7.5.1.3-4.
In Hebrew – הבסם.
Portrayed here as a contemporary of R. Aqiba, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
Portrayed here as a contemporary of R. Eliezer, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
He is Rabban Gamaliel’s son, see Introduction 7.5.1.2-3.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
Here Rabban Simon ben Gamaliel is transmitting a tradition in his name, see Introduction 7.5.1.2-3.

This form, ̓Ιούδαν/ יודן / יהודן became a popular variation on ̓Ιούδας/ יהודה toward the later Roman period and replaced the later almost completely in amoraic literature (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 299-327), and in later inscriptions. Thus the cemetery from Jaffa displays two cases of יודן, (CIJ, no. II, 892, 900) but no יהודה. Naveh’s corpus of Semitic synagogue inscriptions (OSM, index, 152) mentions three יהודה and ten יודן. This proportion is also attested in the 3rd C Beit Shearim catacombs. For the ן suffix, see Introduction 2.4.3.2. See also Zunz, Namen, 22. In tannaitic literature and earlier sources this form is seldom found.
On this title see Introduction 3.2.1.
In Hebrew – איש צידן.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
And in PT always יהודה בן פפוס (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 324), i.e. Pappus no. 3’s son. And cf. yQid4:4, 65d.
According to tannaitic literature, he cannot be dated, but according to BT (bBer61b) he is described as a contemporary of R. Aqiba. See Introduction 7.5.1.2.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
In Hebrew – איש אבליים / אובלים / אוכלי.
Portrayed here as transmitting a tradition in the name of R. Simon, see Introduction 7.5.1.3-4.
In Hebrew – הנחתם. And see also under Ha-Nahtum (App/M).
Tannaitic literature gives no chronological indication for him but, beginning with PT (yHag 2:1, 77b), he is identified as one of the Bar-Kokhba-Revolt martyrs, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
In this tradition Rabban Shimeon ben Gamaliel of Usha quotes him, see Introduction 7.5.1.2-3.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
In Hebrew – מבית גוברין.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
He is the son of Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
Described in this tradition as R. Aqiba’s contemporary, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
He is R. Yosi’s son, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.

So in the better mss. In the printed editions יהודה בן נחמן. In bMen 68b a story is told of a student, יהודה בן נחמיה, who answered ר' טרפון and died as a result. In bErub63a a similar story is told of יהודה בן גוריא answering ר' אליעזר. See also under him.
Described here as a contemporary of R. Tarfon, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4. In PT he seems to be a contemporary of the amora Resh Laqish (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 277).
In this tradition he is gives evidence about the civil war at the end of the Hasmonean period, see Introduction 7.5.2.

This person is mentioned in PT, but there no date is suggested apart from the fact that the man was a tanna. In BT (bPes 70b) it may be suggested that he was a contemporary of הלל and שמאי, see Introduction 7.5.2.

R. Hiyya is reputed to be of Babylonian descent (bSan 5a). Whether his sons were born when he was still in Babylonia or after his migration to Palestine is not absolutely clear. See Introduction 6.3.1. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.
His father is R. Hiyya, see Introduction 7.5.2.

In Hebrew – איש חוצי. This person is mentioned with this name and in the same context in all mss here and in yNed 11:2, 42c. Thus, he should not be identified (as suggested by Hyman, Toldoth, 2, 552-3) with איסי בן יהודה.
He is described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Yosi, see Introduction 7.5.2.
In this tradition he is described as a contemporary of Yohanan (no. 7) Hyrcanus (135-104 BCE).
Described as a High Priest, see Introduction 7.5.2.

In this tradition, (which is in fact two traditions) he is described as a tanna. We could assume he was earlier, because traditions he transmits relate to the Temple, but since we have no evidence that he is a first hand witness, we cannot be certain, see Introduction 7.5.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 113. On this title see Introduction 3.2.1.

person.note: Flourished in the days of R. Joshua, see Introduction 7.5.2.
Appears in only this one baraita as a contemporary of R. Aqiba, see Introduction 7.5.2.

This probably means “son of proselytes,” see above, n. 99. In Hebrew – גר עמוני. The name Judah seems to have been particularly popular among proselytes in the Greco-Roman period (Ilan, SCI 11 [1991-2] 154-5).
In this tradition he is a contemporary of the students of R. Aqiba, see Introduction 7.5.2.
This tradition has a parallel in tannaitic sources (Sifra, Shemini, Mekhilta de-Miluim 33), but only in BT does this person have a name.

See Introduction 6.2. Here a certain story is told of a student, יהודה בן גוריא, who answered ר' אליעזר and died as a result. A similar story is told in bMen68b of יהודה בן נחמיה answering ר' טרפון. The story may, of course be a literary convention and the name is hardly historical. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Eliezer, Introduction 7.5.2.
In Hebrew – הסבר.

Described in this tradition as transmitting halakhah in the name of Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, which could make him old. However, the tradition is not even clearly a baraita, see Introduction 7.5.2.
Although the story has a parallel in Josephus (AJ 13:289-96), this name is unique to BT.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of King Yannai (Jonathan no. 14 – 103-76 BCE). In the parallel Josephan tradition (AJ13:288-96) he is not mentioned, see Introduction 7.5.2.
Described simply as a tanna, see Introduction 7.5.2.
This midrash is late, see Introduction 6.2.3. Lieberman, Greek, 180, reads בעט בו יהודה instead of בעינן בן יהודה. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.
This tradition describes events associated with the beginning of the war with Rome.

For the inverted form of the name see Introduction 2.7.6. For the αν suffix see above, n. 112. This form, ̓Ιούδαν/ יודן / יהודן became a popular variation on ̓Ιούδας/ יהודה toward the later Roman period and replaced the later almost completely in amoraic literature (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 299-327), and in later inscriptions. Thus the cemetery from Jaffa displays two cases of יודן, (CIJ, no. II, 892, 900) but no יהודה. Naveh’s corpus of Semitic synagogue inscriptions (OSM, index, 152) mentions three יהודה and ten יודן. This proportion is also attested in the 3rd C Beit Shearim catacombs. For the ן suffix, see Introduction 2.4.3.2. See also Zunz, Namen, 22. In tannaitic literature and earlier sources this form is seldom found.
See Introduction 6.3.1.1. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.

Named after his father, see Introduction 3.1.2.

In Greek – προσηλύτου. Note that this person is a proselyte, and see above, n. 99. In Hebrew – גר עמוני. The name Judah seems to have been particularly popular among proselytes in the Greco-Roman period (Ilan, SCI 11 [1991-2] 154-5). Perhaps ̓Ιούδατοςis not a personal name but a designation, indicating that the person now belongs to the Jewish people.

On the suggestion that the ossuary is a modern fake see J. Sievers, “Individual Conversions to Judaism in Late Antiquity: Reconsidering the Epigraphic Evidence,” Dimensioni e problemi della ricerca storica 2 (1996) 36, and 40, n. 5. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.

person.note: In Greek – προσηλύτο[υ] τυρᾶ. On Judah as a name for proselytes see above, n. 99. In Hebrew – גר עמוני. The name Judah seems to have been particularly popular among proselytes in the Greco-Roman period (Ilan, SCI 11 [1991-2] 154-5). The title is τυρα, which Milik interprets as τυροποίς. He also suggests alternatively that τυρα stands for Τυρᾶς, a hypocoristic of the name Τύραννος. If this were so, this person is not included in the corpus because since his son is a proselyte, he is obviously not Jewish. He also suggested it may stand for Τύριου, i.e. that this individual originated in Tyre, Phoenicia. In this case he is included in this corpus, see Introduction 6.3.1.3.

See above, n. 207. The form יהוד is mentioned in the Aramaic section of the Bible (e.g. Dan 5:13) as the name of the province יהודה. Here it is clearly an abbreviation, see Introduction 2.6.2. In ancient Hebrew script, see Introduction 2.8.1.

It was suggested by Grintz, Sinai75 (1974) that this person should be identified with Judah no. 17, the father of Mattathias no. 46, the last Hasmonean king, executed by the Romans in 37 BCE. However we do not know if Aristobulus no. 2 had the biblical name יהודה (Ilan, JQR 78 [1987-8] 12-3). See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.3.

person.note: On this orthographic variation see Introduction 2.3.3.4. For the form ̓Ιούδα see above, n. 167. See above, n. 2. This spelling is more in the tradition of LXX.

This ̓Ιαύδαis an enigma. His name is clearly a variation on Judah. The inscription was found within the boundaries of Palestine and is dated to 172-3 CE. However, he appears as the father of a pagan priest named Titus, in a pagan temple inscription. The name Titus, some time after the destruction of the Temple, could not have been popular with the Jews. Was he Jewish at all? Had he become an apostate? The answers to such questions are not obvious. And see on this Ilan, “Yohana bar Makoutha.” His son – Titus – is, in any case, not included in this corpus. See Introduction 6.3.2. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.
The inscription is internally dated.

person.note: The decision to include this seal in the corpus is a random one. It probably belonged to a Jew, as the name indicates, and it was probably found in Jerusalem, since it is located today in the German archaeological museum in Jerusalem. On dating of Jewish objects from Jerusalem, see above, n. 243. On dating of inscriptions from Jerusalem see Introduction 7.6.2.

The seal is from a museum in Berlin. It is written in square letters rather than the ancient Jewish script, making it later than the First Temple (from which time most Jewish seals date). It is clearly Jewish because of the symbols displayed on it. Lidzbarski, Ephemeris 1, 142, identified the symbols as similar to those on Hasmonean and other Jewish Second Temple coins.
Yardeni, IEJ 40 (1990) 130, dates this ostracon paleographically.

See above, n. 234. This is an unusual transliteration, see Introduction 2.3.5.1. Perhaps the ι after the δ indicates, in this case, ethnicity rather than personal name. In this case it is hardly likely that the name is in itself an ethnic designation, since it is followed by the words τὸ γένος ̓Ιουδαῖον.
See Introduction 6.3.1.4. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.
The inscription is internally dated.

This person is a Jew of Palestine. It stands to reason that he was named יהודה. This orthography reflects the shortcomings of the Judaean scribes of the time, and see also the names Αὔδομος (probably Ε̓δόμος G/M) and ̓́Οκαιμος (probably ̓Ωκίμων G/M – in the same document). Note the unusual ending ουν and see above, n. 112. This form, ̓Ιούδαν/ יודן / יהודן became a popular variation on ̓Ιούδας/ יהודה toward the later Roman period and replaced the later almost completely in amoraic literature (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 299-327), and in later inscriptions. Thus the cemetery from Jaffa displays two cases of יודן, (CIJ, no. II, 892, 900) but no יהודה. Naveh’s corpus of Semitic synagogue inscriptions (OSM, index, 152) mentions three יהודה and ten יודן. This proportion is also attested in the 3rd C Beit Shearim catacombs. For the ן suffix, see Introduction 2.4.3.2. See also Zunz, Namen, 22. In tannaitic literature and earlier sources this form is seldom found. On the double δ see Introduction 2.3.4.
The papyrus is internally dated.

This is the way this name is spelt in the Hebrew mss of Sirach. ישוע is also a biblical form (e.g. Ezra 2:2) but it is only found in biblical compositions of the post-exilic period (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). The form יהושע is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of the Second Temple and Mishnaic period, while the form ישוע is preserved therein for Jesus of Nazareth (e.g. tHul2:22, 24). In the epigraphical and papyrological sources, on the other hand the form ישוע is almost always used. In the post-exilic biblical books we already find this form. Thus the high priest who accompanied the exiles returning from Babylonia is called in the Bible ישוע rather than יהושע. In the Damascus Document, a Second Temple treatise, the biblical יהושע of Josh is spelt יושע (after the more common medieval יהושע had already been inserted by the scribe – CD V:4). Thus the use of יהושע in the later literary sources may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be discerned with regard to the names יוסף/יהוסף, יוחנן/יהוחנן and יונתן/יהונתן, see under them. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages,” 233-6.
The name is spelt thus in the Greek translation of Sirach. The biblical names יהושע and ישוע are both transliterated in this way in Josephus (Schalit, NB, 60) as well as in LXX (H & R Suppl. 84).

Ben Sira’s grandson declares in the colophon to the Greek Sirachthat he translated the book into Greek after the 38th year of the reign of Ptolemy Euergetes (=132 BCE). This means that his grandfather and relatives and contemporaries mentioned in the book date to the 3rd early 2nd C BCE.

person.note: In Greek – Εἰς δὲ τὴν ̓Ιδουμαίαν ἑτέρους ἐπελέξαντο στρατηγοὺς ̓Ιησοῦν υἱὸν Σαπφᾶ τῶνἀρχιερέων. On the title “high priest” see Introduction 3.2.5.

Even though both this person and the next one in the list are both designated ̓Ιησοῦς υἱὸς Σαπφᾶ / Σαπφία, they are clearly different people. Either there were two such persons at the time (which is unlikely since the father’s name is so rare) or, more likely, Josephus had mistakenly used the same name for two different people. They are certainly not brothers, see Introduction 3.1.4. And see further, Ilan & Price, JQR 84 (1993) 198-200.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

On dating in the NT see Introduction 7.3.
In tYeb13:5 he is described as a contemporary of Rabban Simon ben Gamaliel, see Introduction 7.5.1.3.
In mYeb 8:4 he testifies about a eunuch in Jerusalem in support of R. Aqiba’s halakhah, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Joshua, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
Described in this tradition as interpreting R. Ishmael, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
So on incantation bowls Montgomery, nos. 32, 33.
So on incantation bowl AMB, no. 5.
One of the “Pairs,” see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
He is R. Joshua, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

He is probably late and thus an amora. He is, however, included in this list on the principle that all persons mentioned in the Mishnah are included, see Introduction 7.5.1.4. On his possible inscription in Beit Shearim see Beth She‘arim 3, 249, no. 24 (25).

Contrary to popular legend, this person was probably R. Aqiba’s real father-in-law, and not כלבא שבוע, (Ilan, Mine and Yours are Hers, 118-20). The fact that Aqiba’s son was also called יהושע (Joshua no. 28,see Introduction 3.1.1) further supports this conjecture.
Described in this tradition as a relative and a contemporary of R. Aqiba, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
In tMiq 6:3 he is described as a contemporary of Rabban Gamaliel, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
Probably named after his grandfather (Joshua no. 26), see Introduction 3.1.1, and n. 61.
He is R. Aqiba’s son, see Introduction 7.5.1.2-3.
He is described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Meir, see Introduction 7.5.1.3.
In Hebrew – הגרסי.
He is described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Yosi, see Introduction 7.5.1.3.
Described in this tradition as a relative and a contemporary of R. Meir, see Introduction 7.5.2.
In Hebrew – אונייא. On this form see Introduction 3.2.6.
Described here and in other traditions in PT as a tanna, see Introduction 7.5.2.
R. Nehemiah, his father, is a contemporary of R. Aqiba’s disciples, see Introduction 7.5.2.
In Hebrew – איש עוזה. A sage by the name of ר' יהושע בן עוזאה is mentioned twice in bYoma 47b as being quoted by ר' יוחנן. It is probably the same person as the one mentioned here.
He is described in this tradition as a tanna, see Introduction 7.5.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 3. The name is spelt thus in the Greek translation of Sirach. The biblical names יהושע and ישוע are both transliterated in this way in Josephus (Schalit, NB, 60) as well as in LXX (H & R Suppl. 84).

person.note: See Introduction 6.3.1.1.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. This is the way this name is spelt in the Hebrew mss of Sirach. ישוע is also a biblical form (e.g. Ezra 2:2) but it is only found in biblical compositions of the post-exilic period (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). The form יהושע is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of the Second Temple and Mishnaic period, while the form ישוע is preserved therein for Jesus of Nazareth (e.g. tHul2:22, 24). In the epigraphical and papyrological sources, on the other hand the form ישוע is almost always used. In the post-exilic biblical books we already find this form. Thus the high priest who accompanied the exiles returning from Babylonia is called in the Bible ישוע rather than יהושע. In the Damascus Document, a Second Temple treatise, the biblical יהושע of Josh is spelt יושע (after the more common medieval יהושע had already been inserted by the scribe – CD V:4). Thus the use of יהושע in the later literary sources may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be discerned with regard to the names יוסף/יהוסף, יוחנן/יהוחנן and יונתן/יהונתן, see under them. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages,” 233-6.
See above, n. 77. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages,” 233-6. Note also the abbreviated name of ישו, used in the censored text of BT for Jesus (bSan. 107a), see above, n. 36. So in the Tosefta, see above, n. 2. In BT, in the censored section (bSan 107a) Jesus is designated ישו, see Introduction 5.7.3.

Much was made by the media in the 1930s over the coincidence of the name of this person and of his father with the name of Jesus Christ and his father (Josephno. 30). For a thorough review of the issue and a refutation of the thesis see Vincent, “Jésus-Christ.” Note that both names were very popular and other examples of ישוע בן יהוסף are found even within this list.

person.note: Like in the case of the other ישוע בר יהוסף ossuary discovered in Jerusalem (see above, n. 94), this one also caused a stir, as supposedly belonging to the founder of Christianity, see the BBC television program “The Body in Question” (=Heart of the Matter) aired on Easter 1996, in which this ossuary featured prominently.

I assume both ossuary inscriptions refer to the same person because they were found in the same burial chamber and one ossuary mentions Joshua no. 51 (son of Joseph) and the other is that of his son, Judah.

person.note: In LXX this Greek spelling is used to transliterate the name ישוה (Gen 46:17 – H & R Suppl.82), but the Hebrew version indicates that it is here transliterating a different name. Because of the unusual way this name is spelt both in Hebrew (with a final ה) and in Greek (with a final α) this person may, in fact, be a woman (Ilan, IAAR 1 [1996] 60). For ε replacing η, see Introduction 2.3.3.2.

In the Damascus Document, a Second Temple treatise, the biblical יהושע of Josh is spelt יושע (after the more common medieval יהושע had already been inserted by the scribe – CD V:4). Thus the use of יהושע in the later literary sources may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be discerned with regard to the names יוסף/יהוסף, יוחנן/יהוחנן and יונתן/יהונתן, see under them. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages,” 233-6.

See above, n. 3. The name is spelt thus in the Greek translation of Sirach. The biblical names יהושע and ישוע are both transliterated in this way in Josephus (Schalit, NB, 60) as well as in LXX (H & R Suppl. 84).

person.note: See above, n. 3. The name is spelt thus in the Greek translation of Sirach. The biblical names יהושע and ישוע are both transliterated in this way in Josephus (Schalit, NB, 60) as well as in LXX (H & R Suppl. 84). These are the declensions recorded in the document. Note the conventional and the less conventional way the same name is spelt in the documents. For the unusual declension see Introduction 2.3.5; for the double σ, see Introduction 2.1.2.6. Although usually ̓Ιησοῦς is transliterated with a single σ, this scribe shows some knowledge of conventional orthography (σσ=ש), creating an unconventional transliteration. For the α replacing η see Introduction 2.3.3.3. Since the orthographic phenomena are repeated in the documents, we may suggest here a scribal idiosyncrasy.
Named after his father, see Introduction 3.1.2.

person.note: Named after his father, see Introduction 3.1.2.

Documents 21 and 22 were written together and signed by the same witnesses. The signatures are also clear. The name of the father of ישוע who serves as witness in PYadin 19 is missing (ישוע בר י[...]). I assume it is the same person because of the first letter in the father’s name, and because witnesses served in this capacity over several years.

For the unusual declension see Introduction 2.3.5; for the double σ, see Introduction 2.1.2.6. Although usually ̓Ιησοῦς is transliterated with a single σ, this scribe shows some knowledge of conventional orthography (σσ=ש), creating an unconventional transliteration. For the α replacing η see Introduction 2.3.3.3. Since the orthographic phenomena are repeated in the documents, we may suggest here a scribal idiosyncrasy.
See above, n. 132. On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

person.note: These are the suggested readings of the editor. Both versions are found in the document.

note.ref: See above, n. 132. On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

See above, n. 2. This is the way this name is spelt in the Hebrew mss of Sirach. ישוע is also a biblical form (e.g. Ezra 2:2) but it is only found in biblical compositions of the post-exilic period (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). The form יהושע is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of the Second Temple and Mishnaic period, while the form ישוע is preserved therein for Jesus of Nazareth (e.g. tHul2:22, 24). In the epigraphical and papyrological sources, on the other hand the form ישוע is almost always used. In the post-exilic biblical books we already find this form. Thus the high priest who accompanied the exiles returning from Babylonia is called in the Bible ישוע rather than יהושע. In the Damascus Document, a Second Temple treatise, the biblical יהושע of Josh is spelt יושע (after the more common medieval יהושע had already been inserted by the scribe – CD V:4). Thus the use of יהושע in the later literary sources may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be discerned with regard to the names יוסף/יהוסף, יוחנן/יהוחנן and יונתן/יהונתן, see under them. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages,” 233-6.
See above, n. 132. On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

See above, n. 3. The name is spelt thus in the Greek translation of Sirach. The biblical names יהושע and ישוע are both transliterated in this way in Josephus (Schalit, NB, 60) as well as in LXX (H & R Suppl. 84).

person.note: Since the name was found on one of the ostraca designated “lots,” i.e. perhaps those cast by the defenders of Masada to determine the order of killing (BJ 7:395-6), Yadin,Masada, 201, suggested that this was a nickname, given to the person after the biblical יואב, perhaps because of his courage.
For dating of the Masada documents see Introduction 7.8.
This is clearly a variation on the name. For the missing ו see Introduction 2.7.1.
I assume the names mentioned on two ostraca belong to the same person, because of the rarity of the name.
For dating of the Masada documents see Introduction 7.8.

This form is not recorded in the Bible or elsewhere. H. Eshel, DJD 38, 28, associates it primarily with the Hebrew/Aramaic root – חזה. I prefer to see it as an Aramization of יהואחז, Introduction 2.4.1.1.
On dating of this document see Introduction 7.7.1.

So in Josephus and 1 and 2 Macc. Josephus’ transliteration of the biblical יוחנן is also the same (Schalit, NB, 66). In LXX only the apocryphal books record this form (H & R Suppl. 91). On abbreviated forms see Introduction 2.1.3. The biblical books have ̓Ιωανάν or ̓Ιωαννάν. νand νν are variations on the same, see Introduction 2.3.4. In the inscriptional record Josephus’ transliteration is followed throughout, but usually with only one ν. On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1.
On Arist see Introduction 6.2.1 and Cohen, JSJ 15 (1984) 53. The name is recorded elsewhere in Egyptian antiquity (Preisigke, NB, 155). See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.
For dating of Arist see Introduction 7.1.1.

So on the coins. On the interchange of יו and יהו see Introduction 2.6.3. In rabbinic literature and Qumran he is simply יוחנן. יהוחנן is also a biblical form (e.g. Ezra 10:6), but it is only found in biblical compositions of the post-exilic period (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). The form יוחנן is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources on the other hand the form יהוחנן is almost always used. The latter was probably the form used during the Second Temple period. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name יהושע/ישוע, see Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages,” 226-33.
His biblical name follows his great-grandfather (Yohanan no. 4), see Introduction 3.1.3. On the foreign name see Introduction 1.2.4.3. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.3.

I disagree with Meshorer that these coins were issued by Hyrcanus no. 3, since we do not know whether יהוחנן was his biblical name at all (Ilan, JQR 78 [1987-8] 10-1, and the scholars listed there). See also J. Sievers “Jonathan Aristobulus III and Hasmonean Names,” INJ 8 (1984-5) 7-8.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

person.note: On this list see Introduction 3.2.9. Bauckham, Jude, 76, suggests tentatively to identify him with Yohanan no. 19, see Introduction 3.3.
See Introduction 7.4.1.
In mRH 2:8 he is described as a contemporary of Rabban Gamaliel, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
In Hebrew – על החותמות.
Associated with the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.

It has been suggested by Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 334-5, that this person is called after his place of origin (Auranitis) and his mother. In the Mishnah, however, he is designated בן החורוני (son of the man from Auran or Horon) which has nothing to do with his mother. החרנית seems to be an unlikely and late variant (Ilan, Nov Test 34 (1992) 28).
Described in this tradition as an early contemporary of Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.

The man is known by both names in the Mishnah itself, where he transmits the same tradition, once (mYeb 14.2) as יוחנן and once (mEd 7:9) as נחוניה. This could perhaps serve as evidence that נחוניה is an Aramaic rendering of the biblical יוחנן.
In tTer 1:1 he is described as residing with all his family in Jerusalem, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
In Hebrew – הסנדלר.
This title is in fact a distortion of the designation “Alexandrian” and this person was of Egyptian extraction (yHag 3:1, 78d). See Introduction 6.3.1. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.
In tKel BQ 4:2 Rabban Simon ben Gamaliel is quoting him, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
In this tradition Rabban Simon ben Gamaliel reflects on his actions, see Introduction 7.5.1.2-3.
In Hebrew – איש ירושלים.
One of the “pairs,” see Introduction 7.5.1.1. See also Introduction, 1.1.1.2.2.
He is Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
In tSot 7:9 he is described as a young contemporary of R. Joshua, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

Rabbinic literature records both forms of the name for this person, see Introduction 2.4.1.8. For this abbreviated form of Yohanan see Introduction 2.4.1.1. The form יוחא is recorded in the Bible (e.g. 1 Chr 8:16) but it is probably not the same name. On a seal from the 6th C BCE the name יהוחי is found (CWSSS no. 524).
He is the father of R. Simon, see Introduction 7.5.1.2-3.
Described in this source as R. Aqiba’s brother-in-law, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of Rabban Gamaliel, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Eliezer, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
In Hebrew – דמן כפר שחדא / שחרא.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Tarfon, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
Tannaitic traditions give no chronological indications for him. In PT (yTaan 4:8, 68d) he is described as a contemporary of R. Aqiba, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
Appears only in this tradition, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.
In Hebrew – חקוקאה. On this form as indicating place of origin see Introduction 3.2.6.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Judah the Patriarch, see Introduction 7.5.2.
In Hebrew – אוכל חלות.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Judah the Patriarch, see Introduction 7.5.2.
A בן בג בג is mentioned in the Mishnah, Tosefta and PT, but only in this place in BT he is designated יוחנן so the name may be doubtful.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Judah ben Batira, who is of the Yabneh generation, see Introduction 7.5.2.
In Hebrew – סופר הלז.
Described in this tradition as associated with the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.

The form יוחנא/ה is an Aramization of יוחנן. See Introduction 2.4.2.1. It is rather confusing because it also served as a woman’s name, see Introduction 1.5.2. I have chosen (randomly) to associate those cases of this form which appear as a parent name with the males, because in most cases persons are named after their fathers, but see Ilan, Nov Test 34 (1992).

Described as living in Rome, although as a native of the town of Eleazar (no. 51) son of R. Yosi (Joseph no. 36) – Sepphoris, see Introduction 6.3.1. S. Klein, “Bar Iohanes of Sepphoris,” BIES7 (1950) 47-51 (Hebrew), identified him with a certain ̓Ιώνιος of Sepphoris, whose epitaph was found in a Jewish Catacomb in Rome (CIJ, no. 362), but יוחנא of Esth Rab is most likely fictitious, see also Introduction 3.3.
See Introduction 6.2.3. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.
Described in this source as a contemporary of Eleazar (no. 51 son of R. Yosi), see Introduction 7.5.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 101. See Introduction 6.2.3. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.

person.note: See under his brother.

note.ref: See above, n. 23. So on the coins. On the interchange of יו and יהו see Introduction 2.6.3. In rabbinic literature and Qumran he is simply יוחנן. יהוחנן is also a biblical form (e.g. Ezra 10:6), but it is only found in biblical compositions of the post-exilic period (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). The form יוחנן is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources on the other hand the form יהוחנן is almost always used. The latter was probably the form used during the Second Temple period. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name יהושע/ישוע, see Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages,” 226-33.

person.note: I assume this is the same person in each ossuary because the two ossuaries were found in the same burial chamber and one (1244) mentions simply יהוחנן, while the other (1245) mentions his daughter, שלום.

person.note: Klein, Corpus Inscriptionum, 28 (following M. Lidzbarski, Ephemeris1, 312) identifies this יהוחנן with ̓Ιωάννης Δορκάδος mentioned in BJ 4:145. Δορκας is Greek for the Hebrew צביא. Josephus indeed says that he was “one, John, known in their native tongue as son of Dorcas.” On Klein’s identification see Introduction 3.3. On son of Δορκάς see also Ilan, Nov Test 34 (1992) 25-6.

person.note: This is the suggested reading of the editor. See above, n. 2. So in Josephus and 1 and 2 Macc. Josephus’ transliteration of the biblical יוחנן is also the same (Schalit, NB, 66). In LXX only the apocryphal books record this form (H & R Suppl. 91). On abbreviated forms see Introduction 2.1.3. The biblical books have ̓Ιωανάν or ̓Ιωαννάν. νand νν are variations on the same, see Introduction 2.3.4. In the inscriptional record Josephus’ transliteration is followed throughout, but usually with only one ν. On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. Most non-literary documents record the name with a single ν, see Introduction 2.3.4. This declension is recorded in the document.

note.ref: See above, n. 106. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

See above, n. 23. So on the coins. On the interchange of יו and יהו see Introduction 2.6.3. In rabbinic literature and Qumran he is simply יוחנן. יהוחנן is also a biblical form (e.g. Ezra 10:6), but it is only found in biblical compositions of the post-exilic period (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). The form יוחנן is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources on the other hand the form יהוחנן is almost always used. The latter was probably the form used during the Second Temple period. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name יהושע/ישוע, see Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages,” 226-33.
See above, n. 106. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: Milik, LA 7 (1956) 267, suggested that this be identified with the Semitic form יוחי, see above, n. 81. Rabbinic literature records both forms of the name for this person, see Introduction 2.4.1.8. For this abbreviated form of Yohanan see Introduction 2.4.1.1. The form יוחא is recorded in the Bible (e.g. 1 Chr 8:16) but it is probably not the same name. On a seal from the 6th C BCE the name יהוחי is found (CWSSS no. 524).

See above, n. 99. The form יוחנא/ה is an Aramization of יוחנן. See Introduction 2.4.2.1. It is rather confusing because it also served as a woman’s name, see Introduction 1.5.2. I have chosen (randomly) to associate those cases of this form which appear as a parent name with the males, because in most cases persons are named after their fathers, but see Ilan, Nov Test 34 (1992).

person.note: So in PYadin 8.
For the assumption that all these are the same person see Ilan, “Yohana bar Makoutha.”

יוחנא is clearly a Yahawistic theophoric name, usually an indication that the person in question is Jewish. In this case there are several indications that he may not be. Firstly, his father’s name is עבדעבדת (PYadin 16) – a very Nabatean theophoric name; secondly, he signs his name in the Nabatean script; finally, of course, he is found in a Nabatean environment, officiating in a non-ethnic, Roman court of law in the Roman province of Arabia. All these together may suggest that his Yahavistic name was adopted under the influence of Jewish neighbors (Ilan, “Yohana bar Makoutha”). See also Introduction 6.3.2. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 167. On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

I have chosen (randomly) to associate those cases of this form which appear as a parent name with the males, because in most cases persons are named after their fathers, but see Ilan, Nov Test 34 (1992).

person.note: These are alternative readings for the same person in the documents. On the form יוחנה see above, n. 99. The form יוחנא/ה is an Aramization of יוחנן. See Introduction 2.4.2.1. It is rather confusing because it also served as a woman’s name, see Introduction 1.5.2. I have chosen (randomly) to associate those cases of this form which appear as a parent name with the males, because in most cases persons are named after their fathers, but see Ilan, Nov Test 34 (1992). On the interchange of א and ה see Introduction 2.4.2.3. This is the best example available that יוחנא was indeed identical with יוחנן / ̓Ιωάνης. Note, however, that the form appears in a subscription written by a Nabatean (עבדעבדת בר אילותא) and may suggest that the name יוחנן was conceived in Nabatean (and in Aramaic) as יוחנא. And see also the case of Yohana bar Makhoutha (Yohanan no. 89).

note.ref: See above, n. 167. On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

See above, n. 23. So on the coins. On the interchange of יו and יהו see Introduction 2.6.3. In rabbinic literature and Qumran he is simply יוחנן. יהוחנן is also a biblical form (e.g. Ezra 10:6), but it is only found in biblical compositions of the post-exilic period (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). The form יוחנן is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources on the other hand the form יהוחנן is almost always used. The latter was probably the form used during the Second Temple period. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name יהושע/ישוע, see Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages,” 226-33.
See above, n. 167. On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

person.note: This is the suggested reading of the editor, see above, n. 121. This is the suggested reading of the editor. See above, n. 2. Most non-literary documents record the name with a single ν, see Introduction 2.3.4. This declension is recorded in the document. Of course it could be written with a double ν, see above, n. 2. So in Josephus and 1 and 2 Macc. Josephus’ transliteration of the biblical יוחנן is also the same (Schalit, NB, 66). In LXX only the apocryphal books record this form (H & R Suppl. 91). On abbreviated forms see Introduction 2.1.3. The biblical books have ̓Ιωανάν or ̓Ιωαννάν. νand νν are variations on the same, see Introduction 2.3.4. In the inscriptional record Josephus’ transliteration is followed throughout, but usually with only one ν. On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. This declension is recorded in the document.

person.note: On this NT orthography see Introduction 2.1.1.2.1. Josephus transliterates the name of the biblical prophet ̓Ιωνᾶς (Schalit, NB, 67), but the form ̓Ιωνᾶ is found in LXX (H & R Suppl. 93). On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. It is not absolutely clear that this title, used by Jesus for Peter in Matt 16:17, is his father’s name. On the suggestion that it refers to the בריונים, a group of freedom fighters or robbers (depending on the point of view of the beholder) mentioned in rabbinic literature, see Hengel, Zealots, 53-6.
On dating according to NT see Introduction 7.3.

On nameless women like this see Introduction 3.2.7. In traditional exegesis, this יונה is identified with Jonah the biblical prophet (yErub 10:1, 26a, cf. yBer 2:3, 4c; and Rashi to bErub 96a), just as מיכל בת כושי, mentioned in the same tradition, is identified as the biblical princess Michal, daughter of King Saul. However, see Ilan, Mine and Yours are Hers, 187-8.
This tradition is associated with pilgrimage to Jerusalem, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. On this NT orthography see Introduction 2.1.1.2.1. Josephus transliterates the name of the biblical prophet ̓Ιωνᾶς (Schalit, NB, 67), but the form ̓Ιωνᾶ is found in LXX (H & R Suppl. 93). On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. It is not absolutely clear that this title, used by Jesus for Peter in Matt 16:17, is his father’s name. On the suggestion that it refers to the בריונים, a group of freedom fighters or robbers (depending on the point of view of the beholder) mentioned in rabbinic literature, see Hengel, Zealots, 53-6.

person.note: LXX transliterates יונתן/יהונתן as ̓Ιωναθάν (H & R Suppl. 93). Josephus and 1 and 2 Macc have ̓Ιωνάθης. Josephus also transliterates the biblical יונתן/יהונתן as ̓Ιωνάθης (Schalit, NB, 67). Aristeas here treads a middle ground, together with other apocryphal compositions (H & R Suppl. 93). On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. On shortened Greek forms see Introduction 2.1.3. On the interchange of η and α, see Introduction 2.3.3.3.

person.bibl: AJ 13:320 (Schalit, NB, 8); bQid 66a (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 881); Avigad, IEJ 25 (1975) 245-6; AJC 1, 5-24; 4Q448.
person.note: Josephus usually designates the Hasmonean king ̓Αλέξανδρος. Once, in AJ 13:320 he gives the abbreviated version of his biblical name -̓Ιανναῖος (=ינאי, see Introduction 2.4.1.1 and 2.4.1.2), the name by which he is always designated in rabbinic literature (Ilan, JQR 78 [1987-8] 7). This is an abbreviated, perhaps Aramicized form of Jonathan, as becomes clear from Alexander’s coins, in which he is designated both̓Αλέξανδρος Βασιλέως (מלכא אלכסנדרוס=Alexander the King) and יהונתן כהן גדול (AJC 1, 118-34). See also a new fragment from Qumran, where he is designated יונתן המלך (E. Eshel, H. Eshel and A. Yardeni, DJD 11, 403-25). Because we have established in this case that this is an abbreviated, Aramicized form of the biblical name יונתן, all other ינאי here are listed under Jonathan.

In BJ 7:285 a high priest by the name of ̓Ιωνάθης, who is supposed to have been the first to build Masada, is mentioned. The identity of this Jonathan (whether he is ̓Ιωνάθης of the first generation Hasmonean brothers or King ינאי) has been much debated (Ilan, Zion 51 [1986] 357-8). If it is ינאי, than it is the one time Josephus designates him by his full biblical name.

This is the spelling of King Alexander’s biblical name on his coins, see Introduction 2.6.3. The Qumran document has יונתן. יהונתן is also a biblical form (e.g. 1 Sam 14:6). The form יונתן is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources on the other hand the form יהונתן is almost always used. Thus the use of יונתן in the literary sources may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name ישוע/יהושע, see under Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages.”

So in rabbinic literature, see above, n. 41. Josephus usually designates the Hasmonean king ̓Αλέξανδρος. Once, in AJ 13:320 he gives the abbreviated version of his biblical name -̓Ιανναῖος (=ינאי, see Introduction 2.4.1.1 and 2.4.1.2), the name by which he is always designated in rabbinic literature (Ilan, JQR 78 [1987-8] 7). This is an abbreviated, perhaps Aramicized form of Jonathan, as becomes clear from Alexander’s coins, in which he is designated both̓Αλέξανδρος Βασιλέως (מלכא אלכסנדרוס=Alexander the King) and יהונתן כהן גדול (AJC 1, 118-34). See also a new fragment from Qumran, where he is designated יונתן המלך (E. Eshel, H. Eshel and A. Yardeni, DJD 11, 403-25). Because we have established in this case that this is an abbreviated, Aramicized form of the biblical name יונתן, all other ינאי here are listed under Jonathan.
This form is found on a bulla that was imprinted by the king. This is a shortened version of the biblical name. Names on seals are usually shortened, for lack of space, see e.g. under Elyoeini no. 2.
His biblical name is after his great-uncle (Jonathan no. 4), see Introduction 3.1.3. On the Greek name see Introduction 1.2.4.3. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.3.

person.note: In this tradition he is quoting R. Meir, see Introduction 7.5.1.3-4.

The assumption that this person is R. Ishmael’s disciple is not based on a tannaitic text that describes him as such, but on his continuous appearance in compositions associated with this school (e.g. Kosovsky, Mechilta, 15*-16*). Nevertheless, we have no clear chronological indicator for him, apart from his appearance in tannaitic literature, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.

See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
In Hebrew – איש גינוסר.

This is the only tradition in which he appears (although it is quoted twice in the Tosefta). He is quoting Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel but it is impossible to tell how close in time he was to them, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.

person.note: Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Judah the Patriarch, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.

The reading is not clear and this is not the only possible interpretation. One could alternatively read: דברי ר' יונתן. בן אבטלומוס אומר ..., but the citation of the same name, when imparting a completely different tradition in bSan 87b, enhances the likelihood that such a person did exist.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
In BT (bMen41b) and in some of the mss the name given is יוחנן.
According to this tradition he is a contemporary of Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
Unique to the Sifre-Zuta, see Introduction 5.7.2. Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 335-6, identifies him with אבא הדרוס and with בן דורסאי. On Klein’s identifications see Introduction 3.3.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
Described in this tradition as Hillel’s greatest disciple, see Introduction 7.5.2.

Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Simon, see Introduction 7.5.2.

See above, n. 43. This is the spelling of King Alexander’s biblical name on his coins, see Introduction 2.6.3. The Qumran document has יונתן. יהונתן is also a biblical form (e.g. 1 Sam 14:6). The form יונתן is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources on the other hand the form יהונתן is almost always used. Thus the use of יונתן in the literary sources may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name ישוע/יהושע, see under Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages.”

See above, n. 2. LXX transliterates יונתן/יהונתן as ̓Ιωναθάν (H & R Suppl. 93). Josephus and 1 and 2 Macc have ̓Ιωνάθης. Josephus also transliterates the biblical יונתן/יהונתן as ̓Ιωνάθης (Schalit, NB, 67). Aristeas here treads a middle ground, together with other apocryphal compositions (H & R Suppl. 93). On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. On shortened Greek forms see Introduction 2.1.3. On the interchange of η and α, see Introduction 2.3.3.3.

So he appears in PYadin 58, see above, n. 45. This form is found on a bulla that was imprinted by the king. This is a shortened version of the biblical name. Names on seals are usually shortened, for lack of space, see e.g. under Elyoeini no. 2.

So he appears in the Greek document. This declension is recorded in the document, see above, n. 2. LXX transliterates יונתן/יהונתן as ̓Ιωναθάν (H & R Suppl. 93). On shortened Greek forms see Introduction 2.1.3. On the interchange of η and α, see Introduction 2.3.3.3.

This is Milik’s reading in Biblica 38 (1957) 259. Yardeni could not read the names.

person.note: See above, n. 2. LXX transliterates יונתן/יהונתן as ̓Ιωναθάν (H & R Suppl. 93). Josephus and 1 and 2 Macc have ̓Ιωνάθης. Josephus also transliterates the biblical יונתן/יהונתן as ̓Ιωνάθης (Schalit, NB, 67). Aristeas here treads a middle ground, together with other apocryphal compositions (H & R Suppl. 93). On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. On shortened Greek forms see Introduction 2.1.3. On the interchange of η and α, see Introduction 2.3.3.3. This declension is recorded in the document.

See above, n. 43. This is the spelling of King Alexander’s biblical name on his coins, see Introduction 2.6.3. The Qumran document has יונתן. יהונתן is also a biblical form (e.g. 1 Sam 14:6). The form יונתן is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources on the other hand the form יהונתן is almost always used. Thus the use of יונתן in the literary sources may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name ישוע/יהושע, see under Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages.”

On dating of the documents from Qumran see Introduction 7.7.2.

Josephus, 1 and 2 Macc transliterate the biblical יוסף as ̓Ιώσηπος (Schalit, NB, 68). LXX has ̓Ιωσήφ (H & R Suppl. 94). On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. Aristeas here treads a middle ground. One ms. version has ̓Ιώσηπος.

So according to Epiphanius, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 142), see Introduction 2.8.3. This name is like יוסי, see below, n. 96. א and י are sometimes interchangeable abbreviated suffixes, see Introduction 2.4.1.1 and 2.4.2.1. On יוסי and יוסה as alternative spellings, see e.g. in the Tosefta Ms Erfurt (ר' יוסי, e.g. in tBer 2:12) and the Vienna Ms (ר' יוסה, ibid.). On the preservation of Palestinian forms in the Vienna Ms. see S. Lieberman, The Tosefta 1 (New York 1955) 12* (Hebrew).

person.note: Joseph was the second most popular name in the Second Temple period after Simon. Since all other particularly popular names could be accounted for as being Hasmonean names, it is of some interest to note that 2 Macc records this name as that of one of the Hasmonean brothers (Ilan, EI 19 [1987] 240-1). For another suggestion, which identifies this Joseph with the previous one (Joseph no. 4), see Goldsmith, II Maccabees, 299, 334-5, see Introduction 3.3. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.3.
For the independence of 2 Macc see Introduction 5.1.2.

person.note: So on the ossuary. On the interchange of יו and יהו see Introduction 2.6.3. יהוסף is also a biblical form. It appears once and refers to Joseph son of Jacob in Ps 81:6, a composition usually dated to the Second Temple Period. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 70-1. The form יוסף is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources, on the other hand, the form יהוסף is almost always used. The latter was probably the form used during the Second Temple, although it is not a biblical form and makes no sense in Hebrew (the יו in יוסף does not signify Yahweh; it is part of the root יסף). Use of יוסף may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name ישוע/יהושע, see under Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages.”

Immediately with the discovery of this ossuary, the person buried in it was identified as belonging to this priestly family (Reich, Atiqot, 21 [1992] 74-6). On doubts about this identification see Horbury, PEQ 126 (1994), see Introduction 3.3.

person.note: The time described in this text is while Peter was still in Palestine, not long after Jesus’ crucifixion.

The name יוסי is very common. It is listed here under יוסף because it was obviously an Aramicized abbreviation of this name (like ינאי of יונתן, etc., see Introduction 2.4.1.1), as can be demonstrated by several cases. One obvious example is the case of the first “pair” mentioned in mAb 1:4. They are usually referred to as יוסי בן יועזר and יוסי בן יוחנן (see Joseph nos. 44 and 45). However, in several places in BT they are referred to as יוסף בן יועזר (bSot47b; bBB133b; bTem 15b, and see also even mHag2:7) and יוסף בו יוחנן (bTem 15b). Similarly אבא יוסי בן דוסתאי (tPeah 4:2 – Joseph no. 52) is mentioned in BT as אבא יוסף בן דוסתאי (bBer 28a). Finally, a sage who is mentioned often as איסי בן יהודה (Joseph no. 47)is given a series of alternative names in a tradition in BT: יוסף איש הוצל; יוסף הבבלי; איסי בן גור אריה; איסי בן גמליאל and איסי בן מהללאל. The rabbis conclude, however, that his real name was איסי בן עקביה (bYom 52b). In a parallel tradition (bPes 112b) another name is added to the list – יוסי איש הוצל. איסי, יוסי, יוסה and יוסף seem to be variations on the same name. Rabbinic, particularly tannaitic, literature has a propensity for the form יוסי over יוסף, which may suggest that it belonged to a Palestinian milieu of the 3rd C CE onwards. Synagogue inscriptions from Palestine seem to support this assertion (Naveh, OSM, 152, which mention ten cases of the name יוסה but only one יוסף). This or similar forms are not found in the Bible.

In the Mishnah, ר' יוסי is never designated בן חלפתא. A tanna by the name of חלפתא is also mentioned in the Mishnah as dating to the days of חנניה בן תרדיון (mTaan 2:5), who flourished during the Bar Kokhba Revolt and died a martyr’s death in it. In the Tosefta ר' יוסי is also not mentioned as the son of חלפתא, but he is mentioned seven times as passing traditions in his name (tMS 1:13; tShab 13:2; tBB 2:10; tEd 2:9; tBek 2:19; tKel BM 1:5; tOhil5:8). Only in the Mekh. dRI, 176 is ר' יוסי בן חלפתא mentioned. However a variant reading suggests יוחנן בן חלפתא. The Mekh. dRI in general names ר' שמעון “ר' שמעון בר יוחאי” (twenty three times, Kosovsky, Mechilta, 45*-6*) and ר' יהודה, “ר' יהודה בר' אלעי” (twice, Kosovsky, Mechilta, 17*). The form ר' יוסי בן חלפתא first appears clearly in PT (26 times, e.g. yYeb 1:1, 2b) and is then current in Palestinian midrashim, e.g. Gen Rab. In BT this form is also absent but the assumption that ר' חלפתא is יוסי’s father becomes apparent since all the traditions found in the Tosefta in which ר' יוסי testifies in the name of ר' חלפתא are now transmitted as: אמר ר' יוסי: ... אבא חלפתא (e.g. bBQ70a-b; bBB56b; bSan80a; bBek26a). However, in the Tosefta חלפתא is called אבא חלפתא only once (tSot8:6) and the transmitter of that traidition is ר' יהודה. The identification of חלפתא as the father of ר' יוסי is apparently based on bMeila 17b, where ר' יוסי identifies אבא חלפתא as his father (Ilan, “Rabbi Yose Ben Halafta,” in Proceedings of the Fourth International Conference on Jewish Onomastics [in press]).
This is R. Yosi, see Introduction 7.5.1.3.

However, in several places in BT they are referred to as יוסף בן יועזר (bSot47b; bBB133b; bTem 15b, and see also even mHag2:7) and יוסף בו יוחנן (bTem 15b). The rabbis conclude, however, that his real name was איסי בן עקביה (bYom 52b). person.note: The יוסף אפרתי mentioned in yKet 12:3, 35a should probably be identified with him. In the parallel bKet103a – שמעון אפרתי – is probably a mistake. שמעון and יוסף were the two most common names at the time.
In this tradition he is cited quoting R. Ishmael, together with R. Meir, see Introduction 7.5.1.3.

person.note: In two traditions in the Tosefta (tDem 3:1; 6:7) he testifies in the name of Eleazar (no. 31) Hasma, see under him.
He is the father of R. Aqiba, see Introduction 7.5.1.1-2.
In Hebrew – הכהן.
He is described here in association with the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.

person.note: In the Tosefta (tSot 14:5) יוסי בן קטנית is mentioned. In PT (ySot 9:17, 24c) ר' יוסי חסידא ור' יוסי קטונתא are mentioned. Further on his identification see below, n. 151.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.

person.note: In Hebrew – איש צרדה.
A person by the name of יוסי בן צרידה appears in the Sifra (Shemini parashah 8.5), but the intention is probably to this person.
Of the “pairs,” see Introduction 7.5.1.1. See also Introduction, 1.1.1.2.2.

He is described here as one of Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai’s disciples, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

person.note: In Hebrew – איש כפר הבבלי.

This is the only appearance of this person in rabbinic literature as such. No wonder people tried to identify him with the other, more prominent יוסי בן יהודה (Joseph no. 42). But methodologically this is wrong. See further, below, n. 151.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.

person.note: On this title see Introduction 3.2.1.

Most of his traditions, including this one, refer to the Temple. In bPes 57a he criticizes the High Priestly houses. In the Tosefta (tMen13:21) this tradition is associated with יוסי בן יוחנן איש ירושלים (no. 45), but see Lieberman, TR2, 265. See also Introduction 7.5.1.1.

person.note: See above, n. 132. On this title see Introduction 3.2.1. The title אבא appears for this sage in the Mekh. dRI, 205 (Kosovsky, Mechilta, 1*).

It has been suggested by Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 334-5, that this person is called after his place of origin of his mother (Damascus). See however, Ilan,Nov Test 34 (1992) 28. His name probably means that he himself was from Damascus (Sifre Deut 1). Already in the Bible the form דרמשק occasionally replaces דמשק (2 Chr 16:2, 24:23, 28:5, 23).

See Introduction 6.3.1.3. יוסי בן דורמסקית, was apparently a native of Damascus, see above, n. 140. It has been suggested by Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 334-5, that this person is called after his place of origin of his mother (Damascus). See however, Ilan,Nov Test 34 (1992) 28. His name probably means that he himself was from Damascus (Sifre Deut 1). Already in the Bible the form דרמשק occasionally replaces דמשק (2 Chr 16:2, 24:23, 28:5, 23). And see also Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 334-5.
In this tradition he is described as a contemporary of R. Eliezer, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 96. The name יוסי is very common. It is listed here under יוסף because it was obviously an Aramicized abbreviation of this name (like ינאי of יונתן, etc., see Introduction 2.4.1.1), as can be demonstrated by several cases. One obvious example is the case of the first “pair” mentioned in mAb 1:4. They are usually referred to as יוסי בן יועזר and יוסי בן יוחנן (see Joseph nos. 44 and 45). The rabbis conclude, however, that his real name was איסי בן עקביה (bYom 52b). See above, n. 132. On this title see Introduction 3.2.1.

person.note: In two Tosefta traditions (tKel BQ6:18; tMakh 2:10) he is described as a contemporary of ר יוסי בן משולם (=Joseph no. 39), see above, n. 106. In two traditions in the Tosefta (tDem 3:1; 6:7) he testifies in the name of Eleazar (no. 31) Hasma, see under him.
