person.note: See above, 132.
In Hebrew – איש יאני. In the Sifre Deut 9, no. 2 the place is designated ינוח or מנוח or even יונה but the Tosefta version is to be preferred.

Twice in the Tosefta (tKil 2:1; 4) he is described as a contemporary of R. Eleazar (no. 44), ben Shamua, but the chronology of that sage is just as complex, see under him, and see Introduction 7.5.1.4.

איסי is clearly also a variant of יוסי-יוסף, see above, n. 96. The name יוסי is very common. It is listed here under יוסף because it was obviously an Aramicized abbreviation of this name (like ינאי of יונתן, etc., see Introduction 2.4.1.1), as can be demonstrated by several cases. One obvious example is the case of the first “pair” mentioned in mAb 1:4. They are usually referred to as יוסי בן יועזר and יוסי בן יוחנן (see Joseph nos. 44 and 45). However, in several places in BT they are referred to as יוסף בן יועזר (bSot47b; bBB133b; bTem 15b, and see also even mHag2:7) and יוסף בו יוחנן (bTem 15b). Similarly אבא יוסי בן דוסתאי (tPeah 4:2 – Joseph no. 52) is mentioned in BT as אבא יוסף בן דוסתאי (bBer 28a). Finally, a sage who is mentioned often as איסי בן יהודה (Joseph no. 47)is given a series of alternative names in a tradition in BT: יוסף איש הוצל; יוסף הבבלי; איסי בן גור אריה; איסי בן גמליאל and איסי בן מהללאל. The rabbis conclude, however, that his real name was איסי בן עקביה (bYom 52b). In a parallel tradition (bPes 112b) another name is added to the list – יוסי איש הוצל. איסי, יוסי, יוסה and יוסף seem to be variations on the same name. Rabbinic, particularly tannaitic, literature has a propensity for the form יוסי over יוסף, which may suggest that it belonged to a Palestinian milieu of the 3rd C CE onwards. Synagogue inscriptions from Palestine seem to support this assertion (Naveh, OSM, 152, which mention ten cases of the name יוסה but only one יוסף). This or similar forms are not found in the Bible. On this form see also Introduction 2.4.1.9.

In Hebrew – הבבלי. See also under Babeli (S-H/M). As איסי הבבלי he appears in the Tosefta. In bMen 18a, in a tradition parallel to tZeb 2:17, he appears as יוסף הבבלי. In tPar 4:3 a certain יוסף הבבלי is mentioned. I assume they are the same. In PT (yBQ 3:7, 3d) he is designated יוסי הבבלי. BT (bYom. 52b) maintains that this person should be identified with איסי בן יהודה, and also with יוסף איש הוצל (otherwise not mentioned in tannaitic sources), with איסי בן גור אריה (Joseph no. 67), with איסי בן גמליאל (not mentioned in any tradition besides this one and its parallels), with איסי בן מהללאל (identified as an amora in bNid.36b) and ultimately with איסי בן עקביא (Joseph no. 64). bYoma113b even adds יוסף איש צרידה (Joseph no. 44)to the list. This, however, is not very likely, because this particular Babylonian tradition about איסי בן יהודה seems to identify one with the other all persons named איסי in tannaitic literature, and some also named יוסף as one and the same. In PT (yBQ3:7, 3d) the tradition also identifies this איסי with other sages – איסי בן יהודה, here designated יוסי (Joseph no. 47)and יוסי קטונתא (Joseph no. 43). Obviously there was little known about these sages in later generations, although the fact that both BT and PT identify him with יוסי בן יהודה may suggest a more reliable source. And see above – יוסי בן יהודה איש כפר הבבלי (Joseph no. 47).
See Introduction 6.3.1. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.
In tZeb 2:17 he is described as a contemporary of R. Eliezer, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

person.note: In this tradition he is described as a contemporary of R. Judah (no. 52) the Baker, see under him.

person.note: See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
There is no chronological indicator in this and the other Tosefta tradition in which he is mentioned (tTer 8:8), see Introduction 7.5.1.4.

note.ref: See above, n. 132. On this title see Introduction 3.2.1.

person.note: In Hebrew – החורני.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Ishmael, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.

This is the only tradition in which he appears (although it is quoted twice in the Tosefta). He is quoting Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel but it is impossible to tell how close in time he was to them, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.
See above, n. 150. איסי is clearly also a variant of יוסי-יוסף, see above, n. 96. On this form see also Introduction 2.4.1.9. In Sifre Deut 104, no. 46 he is designated יוסי.

note.ref: See above, n. 151. In Hebrew – הבבלי. See also under Babeli (S-H/M). As איסי הבבלי he appears in the Tosefta. In bMen 18a, in a tradition parallel to tZeb 2:17, he appears as יוסף הבבלי. person.note: Mentioned several times in the Mekh. dRI but never in a chronological context, Introduction 7.5.1.4. He is certainly not R. Aqiba’s son.

note.ref: See above, n. 132. On this title see Introduction 3.2.1.

person.note: In Hebrew – המחוזי.
This person appears once in the Mekhilta and nowhere else, see Introduction 5.7.1.
In this tradition R. Nathan (3) of the Usha generation quotes him, see Introduction 7.5.1.3.

See above, n. 132. On this title see Introduction 3.2.1.

person.note: In Hebrew – החרם.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.

See Introduction 6.2. The fictitious character of this figure is very obvious. He is the father of the boy supposedly eaten up by his mother during the siege of Jerusalem. Stories of mothers eating their children at times of famine and siege were a common literary motif (e.g. 2 Kgs 6:26-30). The story of a mother eating her son in the Jerusalem siege is also related by Josephus (BJ 6:201-13) although in his case the mother has a name (Μαρία ΕλεαζάρουMariam no. 7) but not the son. This story is already found in tannaitic literature (Sifra Behuqotai 6:3), although one gets the impression there that the sages considered it as an event of the First Temple siege, because on this event Jeremiah is supposed to have wailed. And see also Cohen, HTR69 (1976) 187-96. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.
He is the father of the boy, whose mother ate him during the siege of Jerusalem, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 150. איסי is clearly also a variant of יוסי-יוסף, see above, n. 96. On this form see also Introduction 2.4.1.9.

person.note: He appears four times in Sifre Num (8, no. 5; 16, no. 10; 146, no. 119; 148, no. 121) but never in a chronological context, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.

person.note: See above. n. 195.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.

His son is mentioned often in tannaitic literature, and in the Tosefta he often quotes R. Meir, e.g. tNid 4:1. In bErub13b he is described as a student of R. Meir. Here in PT is the only source mentioning Joseph as Symmachus’ father’s name. In BT (bBer 13b) the same tradition as this one from PT appears but the transmitter is simply “Symmachus.”

person.note: In PT there is no chronological indication which suggests that this sage was a tanna, but in BT (bKet62b) it is suggested that he was the father of Rabbi’s daughter in law, namely that he lived at the end of the 2nd C CE, see Introduction 7.5.2.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Judah the Patriarch, see Introduction 7.5.2.

See Introduction 6.2. The character of this martyr of the Maccabean era is mentioned in the late Gen Rab for the first time, and should, therefore, not be considered as emanating from a reliable historical tradition. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of the Hasmoneans, see Introduction 7.5.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 132. On this title see Introduction 3.2.1.

person.note: In Hebrew – הבנאי.

note.ref: See above, n. 216. See Introduction 6.2.3. See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.

person.note: Described in this tradition as a contemporary of Eunomus (no. 1 G/M) of Gerasa, see under him.

note.ref: See above, n. 59. So on the ossuary. On the interchange of יו and יהו see Introduction 2.6.3. יהוסף is also a biblical form. It appears once and refers to Joseph son of Jacob in Ps 81:6, a composition usually dated to the Second Temple Period. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 70-1. The form יוסף is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources, on the other hand, the form יהוסף is almost always used. The latter was probably the form used during the Second Temple, although it is not a biblical form and makes no sense in Hebrew (the יו in יוסף does not signify Yahweh; it is part of the root יסף). Use of יוסף may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name ישוע/יהושע, see under Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages.”

person.note: On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
This is the suggested reading of the editor. See above, n. 16. This is Josephus’ version of the name, see above, n. 2. This declension is recorded in the document.

The form יוסף is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources, on the other hand, the form יהוסף is almost always used. The latter was probably the form used during the Second Temple, although it is not a biblical form and makes no sense in Hebrew (the יו in יוסף does not signify Yahweh; it is part of the root יסף). Use of יוסף may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name ישוע/יהושע, see under Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages.”

person.note: See above, n. 3. So according to Epiphanius, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 142), see Introduction 2.8.3. This name is like יוסי, see below, n. 96. א and י are sometimes interchangeable abbreviated suffixes, see Introduction 2.4.1.1 and 2.4.2.1. On יוסי and יוסה as alternative spellings, see e.g. in the Tosefta Ms Erfurt (ר' יוסי, e.g. in tBer 2:12) and the Vienna Ms (ר' יוסה, ibid.). On the preservation of Palestinian forms in the Vienna Ms. see S. Lieberman, The Tosefta 1 (New York 1955) 12* (Hebrew). The reading is mine (but see already Vincent, “Jésus-Christ,” 223, n. 29). The editor has מרי חיסה, but this makes no sense, and there is no reason to divide the words as he suggests. I read מריה יסה. On the interchanges of א and ה see Introduction 2.4.2.3.For the missing ו, see Introduction 2.7.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 227. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: These ossuaries belong to the same person because Yoezer son of Joseph of ossuary no. 1290 could be the son of Joseph (no. 92) of ossuary 1292, orof ossuaries nos. 1298 and 1299, all of the same burial chamber. I have randomly chosen to group these two together.

person.note: These ossuaries belong to the same person because both were found in the same tomb, and one of them is the tomb of this Joseph, the other the tomb of his son – Simon.

note.ref: See above, n. 227. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: In CIJ, no. 1332 the reading is יויכיח (and no photograph is presented) but it makes no sense and it has been suggested by Lidzbarski (Ephemeris3, 50), and accepted by Klein Corpus Inscriptionum, 33, that the text should be understood as יהודה. However, Misgav, Ossuaries, 32, based on the reading of the name on the lid (יהוסף), reads this as יהוסה. This is an interesting form where, on the one hand, the Second Temple long form (יהוסף) is still preserved (see above, n. 59), but on the other hand, a tendency toward the later, abbreviated Aramicized form (יוסי/יוסה) is evident (see above, nn. 3 and 96).

Klein, Corpus Inscriptionum, 24, thinks this Μαναήμ is a father’s name and the man should be identified with ̓Ιώσηπος Μενναίου(Joseph no. 19), mentioned in Josephus (AJ 14:307). On Klein’s identifications see Introduction 3.3.

It appears once and refers to Joseph son of Jacob in Ps 81:6, a composition usually dated to the Second Temple Period. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 70-1. The form יוסף is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources, on the other hand, the form יהוסף is almost always used. The latter was probably the form used during the Second Temple, although it is not a biblical form and makes no sense in Hebrew (the יו in יוסף does not signify Yahweh; it is part of the root יסף). Use of יוסף may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name ישוע/יהושע, see under Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages.” For the missing ו see Introduction 2.7.1.

See above, n. 72. See above, n. 2. Like in LXX, this name is not declined according to Greek grammatical requirements but retains the biblical Hebrew form, including the spirited φ. This coincides with the trend in the NT to adhere to more literal rather than formal spelling strategies, see Introduction 2.1.1.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 227. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

See above, n. 245. In CIJ, no. 1332 the reading is יויכיח (and no photograph is presented) but it makes no sense and it has been suggested by Lidzbarski (Ephemeris3, 50), and accepted by Klein Corpus Inscriptionum, 33, that the text should be understood as יהודה. However, Misgav, Ossuaries, 32, based on the reading of the name on the lid (יהוסף), reads this as יהוסה. This is an interesting form where, on the one hand, the Second Temple long form (יהוסף) is still preserved (see above, n. 59), but on the other hand, a tendency toward the later, abbreviated Aramicized form (יוסי/יוסה) is evident (see above, nn. 3 and 96).
See above, n. 227. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

See above, n. 45. Although the form ̔Οσαΐας is also recorded in Second Temple literature (see under Isaiah), the form ̓Ιωσίαςis very common in this period, see below, n. 93. Therefore I decided to place the name here. ̓Ιωσίας is the Greek יוסי, seeIntroduction 2.4.1.2.

See above, n. 59. So on the ossuary. On the interchange of יו and יהו see Introduction 2.6.3. יהוסף is also a biblical form. It appears once and refers to Joseph son of Jacob in Ps 81:6, a composition usually dated to the Second Temple Period. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 70-1. The form יוסף is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources, on the other hand, the form יהוסף is almost always used. The latter was probably the form used during the Second Temple, although it is not a biblical form and makes no sense in Hebrew (the יו in יוסף does not signify Yahweh; it is part of the root יסף). Use of יוסף may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name ישוע/יהושע, see under Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages.”
See above, n. 346. On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

See above, n. 232. See above, n. 3. The reading is mine (but see already Vincent, “Jésus-Christ,” 223, n. 29). The editor has מרי חיסה, but this makes no sense, and there is no reason to divide the words as he suggests. I read מריה יסה. On the interchanges of א and ה see Introduction 2.4.2.3.For the missing ו, see Introduction 2.7.1.
See above, n. 346. On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

person.note: See above, n. 45. Although the form ̔Οσαΐας is also recorded in Second Temple literature (see under Isaiah), the form ̓Ιωσίαςis very common in this period, see below, n. 93. Therefore I decided to place the name here. ̓Ιωσίας is the Greek יוסי, seeIntroduction 2.4.1.2. This declension is recorded in the document. For the additional ι, see Introduction 2.3.5.1.

person.note: This is the suggested reading of the editor. Of course the name could also be undeclined, see above, n. 72. See above, n. 2. Like in LXX, this name is not declined according to Greek grammatical requirements but retains the biblical Hebrew form, including the spirited φ. This coincides with the trend in the NT to adhere to more literal rather than formal spelling strategies, see Introduction 2.1.1.2.

person.note: This particular witness, who appears often in the Babatha and “Seyal” papyri, has an unusual way of writing his name in Hebrew יוהסף (the ו and ה reversed, see Introduction 2.7.3), making it easy to identify his signature. It is a pity that both Se 49 and 64 are corrupted exactly at that point in this name, so it is not absolutely clear whether this is the same person.

For PYadin 23 the editors read יוסף בר מ[תת] but there is no justification for such a reading particularly since in PYadin 20 a יה[וס]ף בר מנחם is documented. In PYadin 26 the editor read יהוסף בר [מתת] but this reading is even less justified.

person.note: This is the suggested reading of the editor. See above, n. 59. So on the ossuary. On the interchange of יו and יהו see Introduction 2.6.3. יהוסף is also a biblical form. It appears once and refers to Joseph son of Jacob in Ps 81:6, a composition usually dated to the Second Temple Period. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 70-1. The form יוסף is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources, on the other hand, the form יהוסף is almost always used. The latter was probably the form used during the Second Temple, although it is not a biblical form and makes no sense in Hebrew (the יו in יוסף does not signify Yahweh; it is part of the root יסף). Use of יוסף may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name ישוע/יהושע, see under Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages.”

And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages.” For the missing ו, see above, n. 303. See above, n. 59. For the missing ו see Introduction 2.7.1.

See above, n. 59. So on the ossuary. On the interchange of יו and יהו see Introduction 2.6.3. יהוסף is also a biblical form. It appears once and refers to Joseph son of Jacob in Ps 81:6, a composition usually dated to the Second Temple Period. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 70-1. The form יוסף is usually found in Hebrew and Aramaic literary sources of this period. In the epigraphical and papyrological sources, on the other hand, the form יהוסף is almost always used. The latter was probably the form used during the Second Temple, although it is not a biblical form and makes no sense in Hebrew (the יו in יוסף does not signify Yahweh; it is part of the root יסף). Use of יוסף may be seen as a return to the traditional Old Testament pre-exilic spelling. An opposite phenomenon can be observed with regard to the name ישוע/יהושע, see under Joshua no. 1. And see further Ilan, Lĕšonénu52 (1988) 1-7; Tal-Shahar, “The Language of the Sages.”
See above, n. 520. On jars with the same name from Masada see Introduction 4.5.7.1.

person.note: This is one of the very rare cases were Palestinian Jews are recorded in Latin letters, see Introduction 2.8.2. This may be due to the fact that this Joseph was probably a baker, since the impression on the wall in Masada is what is usually designated “bread stamp” impression. The editors suggest that he was associated with the Roman army, before he went over to the rebels at Masada (Cotton & Geiger, Mas II, 211).

person.note: In Josephus two forms of spelling for the name of this person are found, suggesting two sources of inspiration. ̓Ιώεσδρος is thoroughly Hellenized, the cluster σδρ substituting the Hebrew זר (e.g. ̓́Εσδραςfor עזרא and̓Εσδραλών for יזרעאל in the Apocrypha – H & R Suppl. 61) and is, not surprisingly, found in BJ, the book which Josephus wrote with Greek assistants and proof-readers (H. St. J. Thackeray, Josephus: The Man and Historian [New York 1929] 104-5). On σ transliterating ז see Introduction 2.1.2.5. ̓Ιώζαρος, on the other hand, seems to be Josephus’ own rendering of the Hebrew, influenced by LXX (̓Ιωζάαρ – H & R Suppl. 92, see Schalit, NB, 67). On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. The two other examples of this spelling found in Josephus are AJ (17:164) and Vita (29).
On this person and his identity, see Ilan & Price, JQR 84 (1993) 191-2.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

person.note: In Hebrew – איש הבירה. In BT (bErub. 55b), in a baraita, a certain אליעזר איש ביריא is mentioned, but since in the Munich Ms. he appears as אלעזר איש הבירא, we may assume that originally, here too יועזר was intended.
Described in this tradition as a disciple of Beit Shammai at the time of Rabban Gemeliel the Elder, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
In Hebrew – איש צרדה.
Of the “pairs,” see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

On the interchange of יו and יהו see Introduction 2.6.3. During the Second Temple period the names יוחנן, יונתן and יוסף were usually spelt in the long form with an additional ה for Yahweh – יהוחנן, יהונתן, יהוסף. Later on, in the literary sources, these names were recorded in an abbreviated form. The name יועזר/יהועזר lends itself to a similar interpretation. Although the form יהועזר is not found in the Bible, it is mentioned in a Hebrew First Temple seal (CWSSSno. 1073). In the literature the form is always יועזר. In the epigraphic sources it is often יהועזר. However, this case in not so clear-cut. Of the seventeen examples of epigraphic Joezers, only eight are written in the long form.
Bears the same name as his cousin (Yoezer, no. 8), see Introduction 3.1.3.

I assume these ossuries belong to the same person because the three were found in the same burial chamber and one (1351) mentions יהועזר בר שמעון בר קלון, while the other two mention other family members: his wife שלמציון אתת יהועזר בר קלון (1353) and שמעון בר יהועזר בר קלון (1354). Of course the last two could likewise be related to the next יועזר, who is this person’s cousin.

person.note: Josephus does not record this name at all. In LXX it is ̓Εζεκήλ or ̓Ιεζεκιήλ (H & R Suppl. 54, 78). However, the formal Greek declension here is in keeping with Josephus’ (and Aristeas’) orthography. On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1.
So according to Epiphanius, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 143), see Introduction 2.8.3.

On Arist see Introduction 6.2.1. The name יחזקאל, as is obvious from this catalogue, was not common in Palestine. It may, however, have been in use in the Diaspora, as is suggested by the Jewish tragedian Ezekiel (W. E. Nickelsburg, “The Bible Rewritten and Expanded,” in M. E. Stone [ed.], Jewish Writings of the Second Temple Period [Assen, Philadelphia 1984], 125-30). Cohen, JSJ 15 (1984) 59-60, suggests that this translator should be identified with the tragedian, see Introduction 3.3. The name is recorded elsewhere in Egypt antiquity (Preisigke, NB, 95, 146 – ̓Ιεζικιῆλ).
For dating of Arist see Introduction 7.1.1.

This could be short for יחזקאל, but the Bible also documents the form יחזקיה (e.g. Ezra 2:16), of which this could be an abbreviation. The form יחזק is documented on a First Temple Hebrew seal (CWSSS no. 193). See also, Introduction 2.6.2.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

Initially J. Naveh, “The Ossuary Inscriptions from Giv‘at ha-Mivtar,” IEJ 20 (1970) 35, read this name as חגקול. Y. Yadin, “Epigraphy and Crucifixion,” IEJ 23 (1973) 18-22, made much of this reading and the fact that the man found in this ossuary was crucified (N. Haas, “Anthropological Observations on the Skeletal Remains from Giv‘at ha-Mivtar,” IEJ 20 [1970] 49-59). Finally Naveh opted for a less fanciful but more likely reading (CJO, no. 130) – חזקיל – an informal version of the biblical יחזקאל.

This book all takes place on the year of Jesus’ execution.

His son associates with R. Aqiba’s students, e.g. in mKil 2:9, see Introduction 7.5.1.3. In Hyman,Toldoth1, 181-4, the author confuses this person’s knowledge of old traditions about Temple times with his date and assumes there were two sages of this name, but this is unlikely.
Often in the Tosefta he is described in the vicinity of R. Aqiba’s disciples. In tZeb 12:7 he is debating directly with R. Nehemiah, an important sage of the Usha period, see under Nehemiah no. 2.
In Hebrew – איש כפר סמא / סכנין.

This person is sometimes identified with various Christians mentioned in early sources. For a review of the various suggestions and an identification with Jacob no. 12 see Bauckham, Jude, 106-121. Baukham distinguishes between him and Jacob of Kfar Sama mentioned in the tHul 2:24 but I do not, see Introduction 3.3.

person.note: The date as well as the assumption for the existence of two High Priests named ישמעאל בן פיאבי is based on Schwartz,Jewish Background, 218-39. See also above, n. 3. The fact that two priests of the same name represent this House in our list of high priests may account for the curious fact that in the talmudic dirge against the high-priestly clans of the end of the Second Temple period (bPes57a), all are called by one, family name, probably of an ancient forefather (ביתוס, חנן, קתרוס), except for the house of ישמעאל בן פיאבי, which has both a father’s and a son’s name.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. This is the transliteration of Josephus for this biblical name (Schalit, NB, 64) LXX has ̓Ισμαήλ (H & R Suppl. 87). On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1.

person.note: The ישמעאל בן פיאבי mentioned in the Mishnah is of a very different character from the one in BT. The former is very positive, representing the glory (זיו) of the priesthood, while the latter belongs to the blood-sucking families of the high priests at the end of the Second Temple period. Since we have decided in favour of two priests by the name of ישמעאל בן פיאבי, we can perhaps guess that the positive appellation belongs to the former, while the negative belongs to the latter. Historically, this makes good sense, since the second ישמעאל בן פיאבי flourished at the time when the priesthood came under such criticism (D.R. Schwartz, “Κατὰ τοῦτον τὸν καιρὸν: Josephus’ Source on Agrippa II,” JQR72 [1981-2] 241-68).

note.ref: See above, n. 5. The date as well as the assumption for the existence of two High Priests named ישמעאל בן פיאבי is based on Schwartz,Jewish Background, 218-39. See also above, n. 3. The fact that two priests of the same name represent this House in our list of high priests may account for the curious fact that in the talmudic dirge against the high-priestly clans of the end of the Second Temple period (bPes57a), all are called by one, family name, probably of an ancient forefather (ביתוס, חנן, קתרוס), except for the house of ישמעאל בן פיאבי, which has both a father’s and a son’s name.

person.note: We know that the person usually designated ר' ישמעאל is ר' ישמעאל בן אלישע because in the Tosefta (tShab 1:13) he identifies himself as such. In BT (bShab. 139a) a certain יוסי בן אלישע is mentioned in a baraita. However, it is doubtful whether such a person existed, since in its only parallel (Yalqut Shimonito Micha 1:1) he is designated יוסי בן אליקים, an amora mentioned also in bBer9b. Hyman, Toldoth,2, 719, suggested that the original must have read ר"י בן אלישע and refered to ר' ישמעאל.

He is R. Ishmael, see Introduction 7.5.1.2. There is some problem involved with the dates for this Ishmael. In one Babylonian text he is described as a High Priest, officiating in the Temple (bBer 7a), in another he is described as a child taken captive with the fall of Jerusalem (bGit58a). All these texts, however, are late and fictional. In tannaitic literature he is consistently portrayed as R. Aqiba’s companion.
Many sages of the post-Bar Kokhba period seem to have named their sons ישמעאל. May we interpret this as an action in memoriam of the martyred sage?

So the name appears in mss of Arist. Epiphanius, however, has כלב and I assume this version is a corruption. Note however that the root חבי/חבא means “to cover, hide” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 418). חבו is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 175); andamong the Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 404). חבי is a name recorded for an amora of Mahoza in bBQ72a in the Munich Ms. (DS12, 81). The Greek Χάβης is mentioned in LGPN II, 469.

On this affiliation see Introduction 3.2.8.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
This text tells of the death of Mary the mother of Jesus, which occurred sometime in the 1st C CE.

For the א suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.9. The names כלבא and כלבי are recorded in Persian Egypt (TADAE 3, no. 3.26). The name כלבא is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 560) and in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 92). Already in rabbinic literature he is associated with the biblical כלב. The text in yTaan 4:2, 68a runs as follows: אמר ר' לוי: מגילת יוחסין מצאו בירושלים וכתוב בה ... בן כלבא שבוע מדכלב.
In Hebrew – שבוע. On this name see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 339.
This could also be construed as a nickname. A name midrash is given for him: בן כלבא שבוע שכל הנכנס לביתו כשהוא רעב ככלב יוצא כשהוא שבע (bGit 56a). See also Introduction 6.1.1.
Described in bGit 56a during the siege of Jerusalem, see Introduction 7.5.2.

The name לוי does not seem to have had any standard transliteration. For the biblical figure Josephus alone records the forms Ληουείς, Λευίς, Λευῆς, Λευί, ΛευεῖandΛευῖτις(Schalit, NB, 79). For the interchange of η and ε see Introduction 2.3.3.2. LXX has Λευεί, Λευί, Λευείς andΛείς (H & R Suppl. 101). Thus the various spelling are all legitimate transliterations of the name.
On Arist see Introduction 6.2.1 and Cohen, JSJ 15 (1984) 61-2. Forms of this name is recorded elsewhere in Egyptian antiquity (Preisigke, NB, 194-5).
For dating of Arist see Introduction 7.1.1.

In Mark 3:16 in mss this seems to be a variant of the name of this person, since he appears exactly after the mention of Jacob (no. 9)son of Halfai (no.2), and in the previous chapter (Mark 2:14) he was called as an apostle. In Matt 10:3 the name is given as a surname for Thaddaius no. 1, since there it is Matthew no. 16 who is called to the apostleshipin the previous chapter (Matt 9:9), and he is present in the list of apostles. And see also under Thaddaius no. 1 (G/M).
On dating according to NT see Introduction 7.3.

So in Matt. For my identification of this name with לוי see above, n. 17. And see also under Thaddaius no. 1 (G/M).

On second names see Introduction 6.1.3. According to Matt 10:3 this is a second name. According to the parallel in Mark 3:16 it is a name of a separate disciple, see above, n. 17. The idea that this Levi is a Levite derives from the fact that he is associated with songs in the temple, an occupation usually assigned to Levites (Stern, “Aspects of Jewish Society,” 598-9).
His son is described as a Temple official, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
This may be a Hellenized form of the biblical name, see in Josephus’ Λευῖτις, above, n. 2.
In Hebrew – איש יבנה.
Mentioned only here in the entire rabbinic corpus, see Introduction 7.5.1.4. His place of origin may suggest a pre-135 CE date.
He was certainly a Levite, e.g. yBer 5:5, 9d.

He is probably late and, thus, an amora. He is, however, included in this list on the principle that all persons mentioned in the Mishnah are included, see Introduction 7.5.1.4. On his possible inscription in Beit Shearim see Beth She‘arim 3, 249, no. 24 (25).

Lieberman, Greek, 180, n. 186, identifies מנחם, mentioned in S of S Zuta with Hillel’s partner, as in mHag2:2 (Menahem no. 6), as well as with this Menahem.

Described ad loc.within a series of events associated with Jesus’ immediate survivors.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.

Some, beginning with Graetz, Geshichte der Juden, 3, 178, have identified this מנחם with Menahem no. 2. Alon (Jews,Judaism and the Classical World, 332-4) however, disputes this conclusion and thinks this מנחם was one of the sons of בתירה with whom Hillel disputed.
One of the “pairs,” see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.
He is R. Yosi’s son, see Introduction 7.5.1.3-4.
In Hebrew – איש גליא.
See Introduction 6.3.1. The assumption here is that גליה means Gaul or Galatia. On the use of this word in that sense, see Neubauer, Géographie, 317.
This is the only tannaitic tradition in which he is mentioned, but he is also probably referred to in yBer4:4, 8b, and see Introduction 7.5.1.4.
Here he is transmitting a tradition in the name of R. Eleazar (no. 46) the Qapar, and see under him.
Here he is portrayed participating in a debate with R. Aqiba and all his contemporaries, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
In Hebrew – איש גם זו. He is identified in BT (bHag 12a) as ר' עקיבא’s teacher and designated נחום איש גם זו although one must accept the Tosefta as the original.
Described in this tradition as R. Aqiba’s teacher, see Introduction 7.5.1.1-2.
See Introduction 6.1.2.
Described in this tradition as active in the time of R. Aqiba, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
He appears four times in Sifre Num (8, no. 5; 16, no. 10; 146, no. 119; 148, no. 121) but never in a chronological context, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.
In Hebrew – דאריח.

See Introduction 6.2. This story, about a man called מנחם who met the god Pe‘or, is timeless. Its only dating is the compositional context in which it is found, which is tannaitic, but the person referred to could be of the biblical period. Clearly he is no historical figure.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.

See Introduction 6.2. The story of the Messiah being born on the day the Temple was destroyed, is completely legendary. On any possible historical connection with Menahem no. 1, see Ilan, Zion 51 (1986) 359-60.
Described in the story as having been born on the day the Temple was destroyedsee Introduction 7.5.2.
In Hebrew – איש כפר שערים ואמרה לה בית שערים.
Described in the story as having witnessed the birth of R. Hiyya’s sons. See under him.

On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. The Hebrew midrash has מנחם. The Hebrew has מנחם.

Klein, Corpus Inscriptionum, 24, takes this Μαναήμ as the father of יהוספ, whose name is written next to his on the ossuary, and identifies him with Μανναίος(Mannaius no. 2). On Klein’s identifications, see Introduction 3.3.

person.note: This is the suggested reading of the editor. The form Μνασ(σ)αίαςappears in LXX for the biblical מעשיה (Jerem 21:1; 29:25; 37:3) or מחסיה (Jerem 32:12) or הושיעה (Jerem 43:2) (H & R Suppl. 114). All these seem orthographic peculiarities of the Jerem translation and appear to be variations on the name מנשה rather than of any of the names they purport to transliterate. Mussies, “Jewish Personal Names,” 249, suggests that it is both a transliteration of מנשה and a translation of זכריה. See Introduction 1.2.3.
See Introduction 6.3.1.2.

The form Μνασ(σ)αίαςappears in LXX for the biblical מעשיה (Jerem 21:1; 29:25; 37:3) or מחסיה (Jerem 32:12) or הושיעה (Jerem 43:2) (H & R Suppl. 114). All these seem orthographic peculiarities of the Jerem translation and appear to be variations on the name מנשה rather than of any of the names they purport to transliterate. Mussies, “Jewish Personal Names,” 249, suggests that it is both a transliteration of מנשה and a translation of זכריה. See Introduction 1.2.3.

The more conventional spelling of the name משה in both Josephus and LXX is Μωυσῆς(Schalit, NB, 88; H & R Suppl. 115-6). However, in both, the variant reading Μωσῆςis also found. If this is indeed the correct reading of this document, this person bore a very unique name in Second Temple times. DJD 2, 222, hesitated as well and suggested the alternative Ναμωση.
For dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

This biblical name has no conventional orthography in LXX (Μεισουλάμ– Neh 11:11; Μεσουλάμ– e.g. Neh 3:6; Μεσουλλάμ– Neh 12:33; Μοσολάμ – 1 Chr 5:13; Μοσολλάμ – e.g. 1 Chr 5:13; Μοσόλλαμος / Μοσολόαμος – 1 Chr 3:19; Μοσολλόμ – 1 Chr 9:11; Μεσολλάμ / Μεσσαλήν – 2 Chr 34:12 in H & R Suppl. 111, 112, 113, 114). Josephus mentions no such biblical figure. He too uses two different spelling for men with this name. For the double or single λ see Introduction 2.3.4.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

This is the most conventional spelling in LXX. It is also found in 1 and 2 Macc and occasionally in Josephus . It is almost never used in the epigraphical or papyrological documents. On the interchange of τ and θ see Introduction 2.1.2.3. Note that in ms. variants the text has here Ματθίας.

So according to Epiphanius, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 142), see Introduction 2.8.3. For this variant form see Introduction 2.4.2.6. On the interchange of ה and א see Introduction 2.4.2.7.
On Arist see Introduction 6.2.1 and Cohen, JSJ 15 (1984) 52. Forms of this name are recorded elsewhere in Egyptian antiquity (Preisigke, NB, 208-9). See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.
For dating of Arist see Introduction 7.1.1.

person.bibl: 1 Macc 2:1 (H & R Suppl. 109); BJ 1:36; AJ 12:265 (Schalit, 84); bMeg17a (Kosowsky,Babylonico, 1064).
person.note: This is the spelling in Josephus of מתיה/מתתיה, except with regard to the Hasmonean forefather in AJ, where he uses 1 Macc with its LXX orthography. LXX records a whole plethora of spellings for מתתיה: Ματταθιάς(as in 1 and 2 Macc and Aristeas); Ματταθιά; Ματθαθίας; even Ματτθίας (H & R Suppl. 109); Μαθθαθά; Μαθθαίας (H & R Suppl. 105), but not this one. On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. On the interchange of τ and θ, see Introduction 2.1.2.3. This orthography is also absent from the papyrological and epigraphical documents.

person.note: This is an example of the NT independent orthography. In NT the variant Μαθθίας is also found. On NT orthography, see Introduction 2.1.1.2. On the double θ see Introduction 2.3.4. The orthography of most of the inscriptions and papyri is closest to NT, which suggests that it reflects best the way the name was pronounced.

Under מתתיה are listed many forms – מתי, מתיא, מתיתה, מתת, מתתי, מתתא and of course also מתתיה. The reason for this is the great fluidity this name acquired during the Second Temple period, see Introduction 2.4.1.1 and 2.4.2.1. Even Mattathias the Hasmonean is spelt Μαθίας in BJ and Ματταθίας in AJ. Zunz, Namen, 22, sees מתיה as an Aramicized form of מתתיה.
On this source see Introduction 5.7.3.
On dating according to NT see Introduction 7.3.

person.note: See above, n. 2. This is the most conventional spelling in LXX. It is also found in 1 and 2 Macc and occasionally in Josephus . person.note: This is the form found on ossuary 1362, where he is described as the husband of Salome no. 19. In 1361, which is his own ossuary, the formal מתתיה is found. See above, n. 48. Under מתתיה are listed many forms – מתי, מתיא, מתיתה, מתת, מתתי, מתתא and of course also מתתיה. The reason for this is the great fluidity this name acquired during the Second Temple period, see Introduction 2.4.1.1 and 2.4.2.1. Even Mattathias the Hasmonean is spelt Μαθίας in BJ and Ματταθίας in AJ. Zunz, Namen, 22, sees מתיה as an Aramicized form of מתתיה.
On such nameless women see Introduction 3.2.7.

I assume this is the same person in the two ossuaries because they were found in the same burial chamber and one ossuary (1361) mentions the man himself while the other (1362) mentions his (nameless) wife and son.

person.note: These are the suggested readings of the editor. The orthography is reminiscent of one of the forms in LXX, see above, n. 6. This is the spelling in Josephus of מתיה/מתתיה, except with regard to the Hasmonean forefather in AJ, where he uses 1 Macc with its LXX orthography. LXX records a whole plethora of spellings for מתתיה: Ματταθιάς(as in 1 and 2 Macc and Aristeas); Ματταθιά; Ματθαθίας; even Ματτθίας (H & R Suppl. 109); Μαθθαθά; Μαθθαίας (H & R Suppl. 105), but not this one. On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. On the interchange of τ and θ, see Introduction 2.1.2.3. This orthography is also absent from the papyrological and epigraphical documents. On the double θ, see Introduction 2.3.4. In this case it is clear that the same name is intended whether it is spelt with one or two θ.

The person in Josephus thus designated is easily identifiable with the person named נביות mentioned in rabbinic literature. The word Ναβαταῖοςprobably indicates Arabic ethnic provenance, see above, n. 1. Biblical, Gen 25:13. In the Bible this name is used for the son of Ishmael, suggesting it may be of Arabic origin. On the identification of the biblical נביות with Ναβαταῖος, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 341, 345.

This is one of the names unique to Aristeas. In LXX נתן is transliterated Νάθαν (H & R Suppl. 118). Josphus transliterates it Νάθας (Schalit, NB, 89), which is closer to this. On the difference between Josephus and LXX transliterations, see Introduction 2.1.1.1. See also Introduction 2.1.3 for this form of Greek orthography. Νατθαῖος could, likewise, be understood as the Greek orthography of נתאי/נתי, based on the similarity of such forms, e.g. Ζακχαῖοςfor זכאי or ̓Ιανναῖοςfor ינאי, see Introduction 2.4.1.2. However, note that the cluster τθ appears in only one other name in this corpus (Ματθαῖος and its variants, see under Mattathias [מתתיה] n. 5). Since μ and ν are interchangeable in Greek orthography and transliteration (see Introduction 2.5.3), this name could actually be a corruption of Ματθαῖος, a much more common name. According to Epiphanius, the version is indeed מתי, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 143), see Introduction 2.8.3.
On Arist see Introduction 6.2.1 and Cohen, JSJ 15 (1984) 52-3. This form is not recorded elsewhere in Egyptian antiquity. The forms Νάθαν and Νάταν are documented (Forbaschi, Onomasticon, 202-3).
For dating of Arist see Introduction 7.1.1.
The document was only preserved in Latin, see Introduction 2.8.2. This is the transliteration of the name in the Vulgate.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
The story of this man connects the crucifixion of Jesus with the destruction of the Temple.

In amoraic literature he is very occasionally designated הבבלי, e.g. yKet 4:12, 29a; bBB 131a. In the latter ר' נתן is explicitly identified with נתן הבבלי. It is, however, possible, that they were two different people. An interesting story is told about this sage (tShab 15:8), where it is stated that a woman in Capadocia named her son after him. This is a good source for the understanding of the ways names were given in this period.

See Introduction 6.3.1. It is usually assumed that he was of Babylonian extraction because a tradition in bHor 13b mentions קמרא דאבוך (=your father’s Qamra), usually interpreted as the belt of authority worn by the Jewish leader (ריש גלותא) in Babylonia. However, this is only conjecture. In no tannaitic source is he associated with Babylonia.
In tShab 1:13 he describes actions of R. Ishmael that he witnessed as a student, see Introduction 7.5.1.2-3.

See above, n. 2. This is one of the names unique to Aristeas. In LXX נתן is transliterated Νάθαν (H & R Suppl. 118). Josphus transliterates it Νάθας (Schalit, NB, 89), which is closer to this. On the difference between Josephus and LXX transliterations, see Introduction 2.1.1.1. See also Introduction 2.1.3 for this form of Greek orthography. Νατθαῖος could, likewise, be understood as the Greek orthography of נתאי/נתי, based on the similarity of such forms, e.g. Ζακχαῖοςfor זכאי or ̓Ιανναῖοςfor ינאי, see Introduction 2.4.1.2. However, note that the cluster τθ appears in only one other name in this corpus (Ματθαῖος and its variants, see under Mattathias [מתתיה] n. 5). Since μ and ν are interchangeable in Greek orthography and transliteration (see Introduction 2.5.3), this name could actually be a corruption of Ματθαῖος, a much more common name. According to Epiphanius, the version is indeed מתי, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 143), see Introduction 2.8.3. This is the Hebrew version of this name, see Introduction 2.4.1.1.

person.note: The reading is according to Misgav. Rahmani, CJO, no. 280, reported no inscription on this ossuary.

note.ref: See above, n. 8. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

This is the suggested reading of the editor. It is obviously a Semitic name with the root עבד in it (DJD 2, 227). Thus, if the editor’s reading is correct, it belongs to the family of names, of which the biblical עבדי is the shortest form. Such names are recorded in the neighboring Nabatean territories (Negev, Qedem 32, nos. 762-832; in Greek, nos. 2032-5, 2059-65, 2501-6).
Despite the fact that this may be construed as a biblical name, it is here probably a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
For this being a variation of the same name, see Introduction 2.4.2.1.
On dating of this document see Introduction 7.7.1.
Described in this tradition as the father of Hillel’s greatest disciple, see Introduction 7.5.2.

This is an unusual form, though clearly Hebrew and theophoric, because of the ηλ. I guess it is some form of עזיאל. LXX has̓Οζειήλfor עזיאל, ̓Αζαήλ for חזאל and ̓Αζάηλος for עשהאל (H & R Suppl. 7-8, 123). DJD 2, 227, refer to the LXX of Esdras 9:14 and 34, but suggest no biblical name it transliterates.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

The inscription is bilingual. The Hebrew has simply עזרא. This is also the Greek transliteration of the name עזרא in LXX (H & R Suppl 54). Josephus has the more Hellenized ̓́Εζδρας(Schalit, NB, 41) as in the apocryphal book of this name.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
This is the suggested reading of the editorsee Introduction 2.7.2.

person.note: This spelling, together with ̓Αζαριά, is found in LXX (H & R Suppl. 7-8).
On the dependence of Josephus on 1 Macc see Introduction 5.1.1.
On dating in 1 Macc, see Introduction 7.1.2.

For this form of abbreviation see Introduction 2.4.1.1. The name is not documented in the Bible, although the form עזא is (e.g. 2 Kgs 21:18). The form עזי is documented on an Aramaic First Temple seal (CWSSS no. 1116). On עזאי being a variation of עזי see Introduction 2.4.1.8.
Described in mSheq 4:6 as a contemporary of R. Aqiba, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
According to mShebi1:8 his son is a contemporary of R. Joshua and R. Aqiba’s companion, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
There is no reason to assume (with Maimonides, see Hyman Toldoth3, 1155) that this עזריה is the same as the previous one.

In this tradition he is described as contesting R. Joshua and R. Eliezer, but it does not imply that he is their contemporary. However, in tYT1:8-10 the same tradition is followed by a comment by R. Yosi, suggesting that this Azariah was his elder, see Introduction 7.5.1.2-3.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. This spelling, together with ̓Αζαριά, is found in LXX (H & R Suppl. 7-8).
See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: The two ossuaries bear exactly the same inscription, but they obviously refer to two different fathers and sons with the same name. These names must have been common in one of the families that buried their dead in Dominus Flevit.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: This is my reading of the name. It is the transliteration of the name עזא in LXX (H & R Suppl. 7), see above, n. 5. For this form of abbreviation see Introduction 2.4.1.1. The name is not documented in the Bible, although the form עזא is (e.g. 2 Kgs 21:18). The form עזי is documented on an Aramaic First Temple seal (CWSSS no. 1116). On עזאי being a variation of עזי see Introduction 2.4.1.8. I thus interpret the word βερουτος on the next line in this inscription as either a father name or a place of origin. N. Kokkinos “Inscription Badly Misread,” Biblical Archaeology Review21/2 (1995) 24, suggested the name be read together - ̓Αζαβεροῦτος - but I have found no evidence for such a name.

This would be his place of origin if we interpret his father’s name as the name of the city of Beirut. The name of this city is traditionally transcribed Βηρυτός (or Βηρούθ - WGE, 209). Alternative transliterations are also possible, and in light of the geographical origin of the other persons interned in this cave (see under Ariston no. 4 G/M; Eiras no 2 G/F), this is certainly a plausible interpretation. The same problems that govern the question of Syrian Jews are also relevant for those of the Phoenician coast cities. For our purpose, they also count as Palestinian Jewssee Introduction 6.3.1.3.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: The name is usually read עלי בצלים, but that is no name, and the suggestion that בצלים is part of the description of מרים’s position in hell was made by J. Lightfoot, A Commentary on the New Testament from the Talmud and Hebraica 3 (Oxford 1859, reprinted 1979) 55.

See Introduction 6.2. The context of this story (the hanging of witches in Ashkelon) is so legendary, that all figures who feature in this story alone and nowhere else are suspect of being literary inventions.
This story is supposed to have occurred during the reign of King Yannai or his wife Shelamzion (103-67 BCE)see Introduction 7.5.2.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
This spelling is neither that of LXX (̓Αμράμ – R & H Suppl. 16) nor that of Josephus (̓Αμαράμης- Schalit, NB, 9) and yet it seems to be a transliteration of this name.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Judah the Patriarch, see Introduction 7.5.2.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

̓Ακίβαν would be the Greek equivalent of the Hebrew form עקיבא. The name derives from the non-biblical עקביה, see above, n. 1. Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:45. Obviously here the Bible preserves the abbreviated form of the non-biblical עקביה, see Introduction 2.6.4. For this variant form see Introduction 2.4.2.6. עקבי/עקיבא are recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 107).

This is an alternative version in the text. On this form, associated with NT, see Introduction 2.1.1.2.1. G. Dindorf, Epiphanii Episcopi Contsantinea Opera (Lipsae 1859) 421, claims one mss has the version Ραβὶ ̓Ακιβᾶν but this would be a correction by a knowledgeable scribe associating this person with R. Aqiba (Aqub no. 2).
Perhaps Epiphanius identified him with Aqub no. 2, but the dates he attached to him make this unlikely.
So according to Epiph. Pan. 42.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. ̓Ακίβαν would be the Greek equivalent of the Hebrew form עקיבא. The name derives from the non-biblical עקביה, see above, n. 1. For this variant form see Introduction 2.4.2.6. עקבי/עקיבא are recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 107).

person.note: He is R. Aqiba, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

עקביה is not found in the Bible, yet it is clearly a Hebrew name. עקביה is documented in 3rd C BCE Egypt (TADAE 4, 21:4); it is recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 575; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1161).
Tannaitic literature does not give clear chronological indications for this person, but in bMQ 21a he is presented as a contemporary of R. Judah, see Introduction 7.5.1.3.

note.ref: See above, n. 8. עקביה is not found in the Bible, yet it is clearly a Hebrew name. עקביה is documented in 3rd C BCE Egypt (TADAE 4, 21:4); it is recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 575; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1161).

person.note: In mEd 5:6 R. Judah speaks of him as his senior, see Introduction 7.5.1.2-3.

See Introduction 6.2. The woman, ̓́Αννα, daughter of Φανουήλ, is mentioned only in the Gospel according to Luke, in a clearly fictitious section, intended to create for Jesus a biography (or perhaps a hagiography) prior to the beginning of his ministry.
On dating according to NT see Introduction 7.3.
This form is also Biblical, e.g. Gen 32:31.
On persons designated “high priest” see Introduction 3.2.5.

See Introduction 6.2. צפנת בת פניאל, the daughter of the high priest who was raped in the wake of the destruction of the Temple is found only in BT, and from the context could refer to the destruction of the First Temple. The name of this woman and her father is also clearly derived from a midrash: מעשה באשה אחת וצפנת בת פניאל שמה. צפנת שהכל צופין ביופיה, בת פניאל בתו של כהן גדול ששימש לפני ולפנים (bGit 38a). This person, designated “face of God” sees God face to face.
The story about her is associated with the destruction of the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.2.

The biblical פנחס is transliterated in LXX as Φεινεές(H & R Suppl. 154). Josephus uses Φινεέσης (Schalit, NB, 124). However, for all his contemporaries he uses other transliterations. The ς at the end of this name is Hebrew and is not part of a Greek suffix. It is thus, interesting to note that it is omitted in some of the mss dealing with this person. We would have found it difficult to identify this spelling as indicating פנחס had we not had corroborating evidence from rabbinic literature aboutthe last high priest.
In Hebrew – איש חבתא. In Greek – κώμης ̓Αφθίας.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. The biblical פנחס is transliterated in LXX as Φεινεές(H & R Suppl. 154). Josephus uses Φινεέσης (Schalit, NB, 124). person.note: See above, n. 2. The biblical פנחס is transliterated in LXX as Φεινεές(H & R Suppl. 154). Josephus uses Φινεέσης (Schalit, NB, 124). However, for all his contemporaries he uses other transliterations. The ς at the end of this name is Hebrew and is not part of a Greek suffix. It is thus, interesting to note that it is omitted in some of the mss dealing with this person. We would have found it difficult to identify this spelling as indicating פנחס had we not had corroborating evidence from rabbinic literature aboutthe last high priest. This follows the LXX reading.
Malalas describes an event that took place in the reign of Caligula.

note.ref: See above, n. 9. See above, n. 2. This follows the LXX reading.

This (tZab 2:5) is his only mention in tannaitic literature. He is mentioned as transmitting a tradition in the name of ר' יהודה בן בתירא, a contemporary of Rabban Gamaliel but this may be of no significance, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.
Unique to the Sifre-Zuta, see Introduction 5.7.2.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Eleazar (no. 66 – Nehemiah’s son), with no chronological context. See Introduction 7.5.1.4.

See Introduction 6.3.1. This is a special case, for although the sources testify that this פנחס was in Rome when Titus died, this is no indication that he was born there. On the contrary, precisely the time he testifies about was a time when many Jews were deported to Rome as slaves.
In this tradition he is described as present in Rome when Titus died, see Introduction 7.5.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 1. Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:25. פנחס was the name of Aaron’s grandson. In the Bible the name is spelled as a rule פינחס.

person.note: In Hebrew – כהנה.
See Introduction 6.3.1.1.

person.note: See above, n. 1. Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:25. פנחס was the name of Aaron’s grandson. In the Bible the name is spelled as a rule פינחס. This is the suggested reading of the editor.

The name is mentioned in a fragmentary inscription which also mentions כהנ and [כ]הנים.Perhaps this is not a Samaritan Priest of the Second Temple period but rather mention of the biblical priest פנחס בן אלעזר, son of Aaron. The state of the inscription does not allow for any certainty.
On the Samaritans in this corpus see Introduction 6.3.4.
On the date of the Samaritan inscriptions, see Introduction 7.6.6.

So Naveh, Mas I, 43. See Introduction 2.4.1.1. And see also the dirge on the High Priest פנקאי (bPes 57a).

In Hebrew – על הקנין. The text goes on to elaborate on the meaning of the name: פתחיה זה מרדכי. למה נקרא שמו פתחיה? שהיה פותח בדברים ודורשן ויודע שבעים לשון.
Associated with the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
I read thus. The editors read פצחי. On פתחי being an abbreviated form of פתחיה see Introduction 2.4.1.1.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

Klein, Corpus Inscriptionum, 28, identifies this name with the person named Yohanan son ofΔορκάς in Josephus (Yohanan no. 13), because צביא in Hebrew andΔορκάςin Greek mean gazelle. On Klein’s identifications see Introduction 3.3.
Despite the fact that this is a biblical name, it is here probably a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

Josephus transliterates the biblical priest צדוק as Σάδωκος or Σάδουκος. The mss. tradition for our man has Σάδδωκος or Σάδδουκος (Schalit, NB, 104). On the double or single δ, see Introduction 2.3.4. Both are closer to Josephus, than to the main LXX tradition (Σαδώκ; Σαδδώκ;Σαδούκ; Σαδδούκ- H & R Suppl. 132). On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

Graetz, Geschichte der Judäer 3, 485, had suggested that this Zadok should be identified with the previous one. However, chronological considerations make this rather unlikely. About the chronology of this Zadok see under Eleazar no. 29 (his son). See also Introduction 3.3.
Described in mShab 7:2 as a contemporary of Rabban Gamaliel, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

This story, which attempts to explain the names of the sects צדוקים (Sadducees) and ביתוסים (Boethusians) from the personal names of their founders, is a clearly literary creation (e.g. Schremer, JJS 48 [1997]). And see also Introduction 6.2.3.
Disciple of one of the “pairs,” see Introduction 7.5.2.
On the assumption that this is the name of the Teacher of Righteousness at Qumran see B.-Z. Wacholder, The Dawn of Qumran: Sectarian Torah and the Teacher of Righteousness (Cincinnati 1983) 112-9.
On dating of the Qumran material see Introduction 7.7.2
This is how the biblical צדקיה is transliterated in LXX.
So according to Epiphanius, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 143), see Introduction 2.8.3. On the interchange of ה and א see Introduction 2.4.2.7.
On Arist see Introduction 6.2.1 and Cohen, JSJ 15 (1984) 60. This name is not recorded elsewhere in Egyptian antiquity.
For dating of Arist see Introduction 7.1.1.

LXX transliterates the biblical name Σοφονίας (H & R Suppl. 147). While the Greek names Σόφων and Σοφωνιανός are recorded (WGE, 1431 and elsewhere), this particular form is absent. It seems a combination between the Greek name and the Hellenized biblical name. I think the biblical name was intended because all other people mentioned in this list in the Clementine Homilies have biblical names.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
The time described in this text is while Peter was still in Palestine, not long after Jesus’ crucifixion.

This follows the orthographic tradition of Josephus (̔Ρουβῆλος – Schalit, NB, 102). LXX has ̔Ρουβήν(H & R Suppl. 130-1). What gave rise to the λ in Josephus is hard to say. There are no parallel examples in this corpus. On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. On this transliteration and its possible cultural connections see Cohen, JSJ 7 (1976) 117-28. Other versions in the mss also record ̔Ρουβήν and ̔Ρουβίμ.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
The events in this booktook place sometime before Mary’s birth.

What gave rise to the λ in Josephus is hard to say. There are no parallel examples in this corpus. On the difference in transliteration between Josephus and LXX see Introduction 2.1.1.1. On this transliteration and its possible cultural connections see Cohen, JSJ 7 (1976) 117-28. Other versions in the mss also record ̔Ρουβήν and ̔Ρουβίμ.

See above, 3.
The time described in this text is while Peter was still in Palestine, not long after Jesus’ crucifixion.
In this tradition Hananiah (no. 18) ben Hakhinai relates an episode associated with him, and see under him.
This is the earliest text in which he appears but a clearer chronological context of post-135 CE is found in bMeila17a, see Introduction 7.5.2.

Should perhaps be identified with Reuben no. 4, mentioned in PT, and also in BT in similar circumstances (bMeila 17a), but the traditions are not so similar as to render such an identification methodologically justifiable.

He is described in association with the house of Rabban Gamaliel, but the connection may be editorial and not integral. Thus, we are left with the baraita form of the tradition, see Introduction 7.5.2.

A new reading of this ossuary is suggested by Fritz & Deines, IEJ 49 (1999) 225: [-]ארבגלא בן [-] but even if the reading is more sound paleographically, it makes no sense onomastically. Thus I stick with the old reading. Either this should be seen as an Aramization (Introduction 2.4.2.9), in which case for the final ן in a medial position see Introduction 2.7.5, or as a scribal error, where the א was added as an afterthought and in the wrong position. רובן would be the way the name was pronounced. On the decline of the gutturals and the fall of the א see Introduction 2.5.1.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

As a name רבין is recorded from the amoraic period (Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1500-6). Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 35-50, 637, assumes the name is a form of ר' אבין. I assume here that it is a variation on ראובן.

note.ref: See above, n. 14. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

Thus I stick with the old reading. Either this should be seen as an Aramization (Introduction 2.4.2.9), in which case for the final ן in a medial position see Introduction 2.7.5, or as a scribal error, where the א was added as an afterthought and in the wrong position. רובן would be the way the name was pronounced. On the decline of the gutturals and the fall of the א see Introduction 2.5.1.

Thus I stick with the old reading. Either this should be seen as an Aramization (Introduction 2.4.2.9), in which case for the final ן in a medial position see Introduction 2.7.5, or as a scribal error, where the א was added as an afterthought and in the wrong position. רובן would be the way the name was pronounced. On the decline of the gutturals and the fall of the א see Introduction 2.5.1. This is the suggested reading of the editor.

Perhaps they are indicative of a pronunciation tradition (e.g. Lipińksi, Studies 2, 209), and see Introduction 2.1.2.1. ̓Αρέγετοςis completely obscure.

person.note: This name appears only once in Josephus within the following sentence: ...πατὴρ μὲν γενόμενος ἐκ μιᾶς γυναικὸς παίδιων ἑπτά , ποισάμενος δὲ καὶ ἐκ τῆς τοῦ ἀδελφοῦ Σολυμίου θυγατρὸς ἕνα ̔Υρκανόν. Since both ἀδελφοῦ and Σολυμίου as well as Σολυμίου and θυγατρὸς are in the genetive, one may assume that Σολυμίου describes either father or daughter. Scholars have usually opted for the male name, because it seems to decline the name Σολυμίος, which seems male. I have left it at that.However, since names with the root שלום were much more common for women than men at the time, this reconstruction is not the only possible one.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

person.note: Although LXX has simply Σήμ (H & R Suppl. 144) Josephus has Σημᾶς (e.g. AJ 1:109). This is probably the biblical name this Christian author had in mind. The forms Σῆμ, Σῆμε, Σημαῆς and Σήμαιοςare recordedon Egyptian papyri (Preisigke, NB, 382; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 292). It could also derive from the Hebrew שמש. Names with this element are recorded among Idumeans (AOFCI, 100). The name שמס is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 358). The name שמשו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 1163).

His son is usually identified as any R. Eleazar in Tannaitic literature. No tannaitic source definitely gives a satisfactory date for ר' אלעזר בן שמוע. The problem for ר' אלעזר is just as complex, since several dates are possible. E.g. in tPes 2:11 he is described as a contemporary of Rabban Gamaliel, but in tNaz 3: 18 he is described as a contemporary of R. Yosi, R. Judah and R. Meir, see Introduction 7.5.1.3.

The form Σίμωνis clearly a Greek name (WGE, 1393-4). It was, however, adopted early in the Hellenistic period as the Greek equivalent of the biblical שמעון, see Introduction 1.2.3. It is true that Josephus makes the distinction and uses the form Συμεών (Σεμεών) for the biblical son of Joseph (Schalit, NB, 110) and Σίμων(Schalit, NB, 113) for his contemporaries of this name. LXX likewise uses Συμεών for the son of Jacob (H & R Suppl. 148) while using Σίμωνfor persons mentioned in the apocrypha. However, the שמעון mentioned in Ezra 10:31 is transliterated Σίμων in LXX, indicating the fluidity of the forms. Some scholars make much of the distinction (Cohen, JSJ 7 [1976] 112, and particularly n. 74; Schlatter, HN, 111). However, this is not justified, since the distinction is often non-existent. Thus, apart from the example here, we can also mention the person who is designated in rabbinic literature שמעון הצדיק (e.g. mAb1:2) and whose name is spelled by Josephus simply Σίμων. Furthermore, most of the people by this name mentioned in Josephus, particularly all those mentioned in AJ, where Josephus was his own proof-reader and decided about his own spelling, are Σίμων. This is hardly an indication that these all bore the Greek name, but rather that for Josephus there was really no difference. Hebrew literature, however, does preserve the form סימון, which is clearly the equivalent of the Greek Σίμων. Here the two are listed together.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. The form Σίμωνis clearly a Greek name (WGE, 1393-4). It was, however, adopted early in the Hellenistic period as the Greek equivalent of the biblical שמעון, see Introduction 1.2.3. It is true that Josephus makes the distinction and uses the form Συμεών (Σεμεών) for the biblical son of Joseph (Schalit, NB, 110) and Σίμων(Schalit, NB, 113) for his contemporaries of this name. LXX likewise uses Συμεών for the son of Jacob (H & R Suppl. 148) while using Σίμωνfor persons mentioned in the apocrypha. However, the שמעון mentioned in Ezra 10:31 is transliterated Σίμων in LXX, indicating the fluidity of the forms. In Hebrew – הצדיק; in Greek – ̔ καὶ δίκαιος ἐπικληθείς.

See Introduction, 1.1.1.2.2. On the problems of identity and chronology of Simon the Just, see Appendix B, in R. Marcus’ translation of Josephus’ AJ 12-14 (vol. vii) in the Leob Classical Library (Cambridge MA 1957) 732-6. Feldman claims that the title (and thus the person mentioned in rabbinic literature and Sirach) more likely belongs to Simon II. I have preferred to go with Josephus formal identification. For further identification problems, see the note in L.H. Feldman’s translation of AJ 19:297 (pp. 354-5), in the same series (vol. ix, 1965).

person.note: See Introduction, 1.1.1.2.2. Ben Sira’s grandson declares in the colophon to the Greek Sirachthat he translated the book into Greek after the 38th year of the reign of Ptolemy Euergetes (=132 BCE). This means that his grandfather and relatives and contemporaries mentioned in the book date to the 3rd early 2nd C BCE.

See above, n. 2. The form Σίμωνis clearly a Greek name (WGE, 1393-4). It was, however, adopted early in the Hellenistic period as the Greek equivalent of the biblical שמעון, see Introduction 1.2.3. See Introduction 1.1.1.2.2-3.
On the dependence of Josephus on 1 Macc see Introduction 5.1.1.
On dating in 1 Macc see Introduction 7.1.2.

This is an interesting example where in the earlier version (BJ), where Josephus had proofreaders, the name is spelled Συμεών, like in the earlier parts of LXX, but in Vita, where he was his own proofreader, he uses the Hellenized Σίμων. This is also a case where a Hebrew שמעון is transliterated as Σίμων.
Perhaps named after his grandfather (Simon no. 84), see Introduction 3.1.1.

Perhaps this שמעון is mentioned also in tSot13:4 (as the martyr, the counterpart of ישמעאל) and in ySot9:14, 24b and bSot 48b, as suggested by e.g. Hyman, Toldoth 3, 1163, but this is the only place where the reference is clearly to the Συμεών mentioned in Josephus.

note.ref: See above, n. 31. On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

See above, n. 2. The form Σίμωνis clearly a Greek name (WGE, 1393-4). It was, however, adopted early in the Hellenistic period as the Greek equivalent of the biblical שמעון, see Introduction 1.2.3. It is true that Josephus makes the distinction and uses the form Συμεών (Σεμεών) for the biblical son of Joseph (Schalit, NB, 110) and Σίμων(Schalit, NB, 113) for his contemporaries of this name. LXX likewise uses Συμεών for the son of Jacob (H & R Suppl. 148) while using Σίμωνfor persons mentioned in the apocrypha. However, the שמעון mentioned in Ezra 10:31 is transliterated Σίμων in LXX, indicating the fluidity of the forms. Some scholars make much of the distinction (Cohen, JSJ 7 [1976] 112, and particularly n. 74; Schlatter, HN, 111). However, this is not justified, since the distinction is often non-existent. Thus, apart from the example here, we can also mention the person who is designated in rabbinic literature שמעון הצדיק (e.g. mAb1:2) and whose name is spelled by Josephus simply Σίμων. Furthermore, most of the people by this name mentioned in Josephus, particularly all those mentioned in AJ, where Josephus was his own proof-reader and decided about his own spelling, are Σίμων. This is hardly an indication that these all bore the Greek name, but rather that for Josephus there was really no difference. Hebrew literature, however, does preserve the form סימון, which is clearly the equivalent of the Greek Σίμων. Here the two are listed together.

person.note: Here the NT is using the LXX spelling. See above, n. 48. See above, n. 2. This is an interesting example where in the earlier version (BJ), where Josephus had proofreaders, the name is spelled Συμεών, like in the earlier parts of LXX, but in Vita, where he was his own proofreader, he uses the Hellenized Σίμων. This is also a case where a Hebrew שמעון is transliterated as Σίμων.

In Hebrew – התימני. This could mean that he comes from Yemen. It could simply means that he comes from the south (תימן is south in the Bible). For another suggestion see Neubauer, Geographie, 279-80.
In tBer 4:18 he is described in the company of R. Aqiba’s contemporaries, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

This is the only place in the Mishnah where he is mentioned in his full name. As בן זומא he appears several times, usually in association with R. Joshua (e.g. mNaz 8:1), see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

This is an only appearance of this person in rabbinic literature. Some mss read שמעון בן עזאי instead, but this version seems to me to be the lectio difficilior. There is no way of deciding the date of this sage, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.

He appears seldom in tannaitic literature. In this tradition he comments on a dispute between R. Eliezer and R. Joshua but we need not assume that he is their contemporary, see Introduction 7.5.1.4. Neither do we need to assume that he is Azariah no. 3.
From tannaitic literature his date cannot be fixed, but in amoraic literature he seems to be the contemporary of R. Judah the Patriarch (e.g. yBer 1:1, 2c). And see Introduction 7.5.1.4.
In this tradition he is described as a contemporary of Rabban Simon ben Gamaliel, see Introduction 7.5.1.3.
סימי is the Aramicized diminutive of the Greek סימון, see Introduction 2.4.1.1. On סימי-סימאי see Introduction 2.4.1.8. See also Introduction 2.4.1.9.

Appears only here and in Sifre Deut 340-1, no. 306, but with no chronological indicators, seeIntroduction 7.5.1.4. In bHul56b, however, he is mentioned with R. Zadoq, a rabbi who flourished before and after the destruction of Jerusalem.

See Introduction 6.2. This person is the missing link between הלל the Elder and the patriarchal family of רבן גמליאל. He is not mentioned in any source save this one, which is a literary construction. Scholars have long considered him a literary invention, as even the relationship between הלל and the גמליאל family is (Goodblatt, Monarchic Principle, 210). See also Introduction 1.1.1.2.1.
He is the supposed father of Rabban Gamaliel the Elder, see Introduction 7.5.2.

person.note: Described in this tradition both as residing in Jerusalem and as a contemporary of Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai, see Introduction 7.5.2.

See above, n. 2. The form Σίμωνis clearly a Greek name (WGE, 1393-4). It was, however, adopted early in the Hellenistic period as the Greek equivalent of the biblical שמעון, see Introduction 1.2.3. It is true that Josephus makes the distinction and uses the form Συμεών (Σεμεών) for the biblical son of Joseph (Schalit, NB, 110) and Σίμων(Schalit, NB, 113) for his contemporaries of this name. LXX likewise uses Συμεών for the son of Jacob (H & R Suppl. 148) while using Σίμωνfor persons mentioned in the apocrypha. However, the שמעון mentioned in Ezra 10:31 is transliterated Σίμων in LXX, indicating the fluidity of the forms. Some scholars make much of the distinction (Cohen, JSJ 7 [1976] 112, and particularly n. 74; Schlatter, HN, 111). However, this is not justified, since the distinction is often non-existent. Thus, apart from the example here, we can also mention the person who is designated in rabbinic literature שמעון הצדיק (e.g. mAb1:2) and whose name is spelled by Josephus simply Σίμων. Furthermore, most of the people by this name mentioned in Josephus, particularly all those mentioned in AJ, where Josephus was his own proof-reader and decided about his own spelling, are Σίμων. This is hardly an indication that these all bore the Greek name, but rather that for Josephus there was really no difference. Hebrew literature, however, does preserve the form סימון, which is clearly the equivalent of the Greek Σίμων. Here the two are listed together. The declension is recorded in the document.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

I assume this is the same person in each of the ossuaries because the three ossuaries were found in the same burial chamber and two (1350, 1351) mention יהוסף בר שמעון of the קלון family and יהועזר בר שמעון of the קלון family, but only ossuary 1355 mentions Σίμωνος as the father of no-one. I assume they are one and the same person.

person.note: For this reading see Misgav, Ossuaries, 78. The original publication has קימו. This is a clear case where the Greek name Σιμών is intended. This form is reminiscent of סימי (see above, n. 154) with a ו (Nabatean) suffix, see Introduction 2.4.5.1. It is also reminiscent of the Latin “Simo,” see above, n. 30. This is the way Tacitus transliterated the name into Latin, see Introduction 2.8.2. He obviously assumed that Σίμων was a Greek name and the ν in the end was not part of the name.

It has been suggested by Milik, DF, 81 (and also J. P. Kane, “The Ossuary Inscriptions of Jerusalem, JSS 23 [1978] 278-9) that this person should be identified with Simon of Cyrene who carried Jesus’ cross (Mark 15.21) both because he is designated here, like there, father of Alexander, and because his designation here (קרנית) may be explained as deriving from his place of origin – Cyrene, see Introduction 3.3.

person.note: On the ossuary the name is recorded in Greek, see above, n. 2. The form Σίμωνis clearly a Greek name (WGE, 1393-4). It was, however, adopted early in the Hellenistic period as the Greek equivalent of the biblical שמעון, see Introduction 1.2.3. It is true that Josephus makes the distinction and uses the form Συμεών (Σεμεών) for the biblical son of Joseph (Schalit, NB, 110) and Σίμων(Schalit, NB, 113) for his contemporaries of this name. LXX likewise uses Συμεών for the son of Jacob (H & R Suppl. 148) while using Σίμωνfor persons mentioned in the apocrypha. However, the שמעון mentioned in Ezra 10:31 is transliterated Σίμων in LXX, indicating the fluidity of the forms. Some scholars make much of the distinction (Cohen, JSJ 7 [1976] 112, and particularly n. 74; Schlatter, HN, 111). However, this is not justified, since the distinction is often non-existent. Thus, apart from the example here, we can also mention the person who is designated in rabbinic literature שמעון הצדיק (e.g. mAb1:2) and whose name is spelled by Josephus simply Σίμων. Furthermore, most of the people by this name mentioned in Josephus, particularly all those mentioned in AJ, where Josephus was his own proof-reader and decided about his own spelling, are Σίμων. This is hardly an indication that these all bore the Greek name, but rather that for Josephus there was really no difference. Hebrew literature, however, does preserve the form סימון, which is clearly the equivalent of the Greek Σίμων. Here the two are listed together. The declension is recorded in the document. The platter has the Hebrew שמעון.
The ossuary and bowl were found in the same tomb and obviously belonged to the same person. Two of the persons mentioned on the bowl arealso mentioned on ossuaries. This is one of them.

The Judaean Desert documents were able to prove that the famous Jewish rebel leader of 132-5 CE – Bar Kokhba according to Eusebius, EH, 4:6, and Ben Kuziba according to PT (yTaan4:7, 48d) – was called by the personal name, Simon. This also proves that the coins carrying the legend שמעון נשיא ישראל, are those issued by Bar Kokhba (Milik, RB 60 [1953] 277).
These are the dates of the Bar Kokhba Revolt, named after this person.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
