person.note: The editors transliterated Φάλων into Hebrew as פלוני and interpreted it as some kind of title. I prefer to read it as the father’s name, and assume that the documents record three brothers in the service of Bar Kokhba.

note.ref: See above, n. 317. On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

See above, n. 2. The form Σίμωνis clearly a Greek name (WGE, 1393-4). It was, however, adopted early in the Hellenistic period as the Greek equivalent of the biblical שמעון, see Introduction 1.2.3. It is true that Josephus makes the distinction and uses the form Συμεών (Σεμεών) for the biblical son of Joseph (Schalit, NB, 110) and Σίμων(Schalit, NB, 113) for his contemporaries of this name. LXX likewise uses Συμεών for the son of Jacob (H & R Suppl. 148) while using Σίμωνfor persons mentioned in the apocrypha. However, the שמעון mentioned in Ezra 10:31 is transliterated Σίμων in LXX, indicating the fluidity of the forms. Some scholars make much of the distinction (Cohen, JSJ 7 [1976] 112, and particularly n. 74; Schlatter, HN, 111). However, this is not justified, since the distinction is often non-existent. Thus, apart from the example here, we can also mention the person who is designated in rabbinic literature שמעון הצדיק (e.g. mAb1:2) and whose name is spelled by Josephus simply Σίμων. Furthermore, most of the people by this name mentioned in Josephus, particularly all those mentioned in AJ, where Josephus was his own proof-reader and decided about his own spelling, are Σίμων. This is hardly an indication that these all bore the Greek name, but rather that for Josephus there was really no difference. Hebrew literature, however, does preserve the form סימון, which is clearly the equivalent of the Greek Σίμων. Here the two are listed together.

Furthermore, most of the people by this name mentioned in Josephus, particularly all those mentioned in AJ, where Josephus was his own proof-reader and decided about his own spelling, are Σίμων. This is hardly an indication that these all bore the Greek name, but rather that for Josephus there was really no difference. Hebrew literature, however, does preserve the form סימון, which is clearly the equivalent of the Greek Σίμων. Here the two are listed together. The declension is recorded in the documents.

See Introduction 6.2. אחיה and שמעיה are mentioned as two brothers martyred by the emperor Trajan, but the reliability of this tradition is suspect not only because it is not recorded earlier than BT, but also because on the same page two other famous brothers who were martyred by Trajan –Pappus no. 4 and Lollianus no. 1 – are mentioned as a form of alternative tradition.

Josephus transliterates biblical שת as Σῆθος, but in LXX it is transliterated Σέθ(H & R Suppl. 144) as here. On the interchange of ε and η, see Introduction 2.3.3.2.

This could be a variation on the name. See above, n. 2. Josephus transliterates biblical שת as Σῆθος, but in LXX it is transliterated Σέθ(H & R Suppl. 144) as here. div.note: Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 14:1. אביה was the name of an Israelite prince. It is also the name of a biblical priestly course: 1 Chr 24:10, see Introduction 1.1.1.3.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 22:20. אביתר was a priest under King David.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 17:5. אברהם is the name of the famous biblical patriarch, forefather of the Jewish people. The name was not in use by Jews in Palestine during the Second Temple and Mishnaic periods, probably due to the veneration with which it was held, see Introduction, 1.1.1.1; Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 325. For very different reasons, forms of it were popular in the Diaspora, particularly in Egypt, see Cohen, JSJ 7 (1976) 99-112. See also Mussies, “Jewish Personal Names,” 250. Use of Abraham as a name of two Septuagint translators in the Letter of Aristeas probably proves the fictitious character of this list, or alternatively its Egyptian provenance, see Introduction 6.2.1. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 10-1.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 3:3. אבשלום was David’s rebellious son (Introduction 1.1.1.1). For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 11.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 16:28. אחאב was the name of a king of Israel. For rabbinic etymology of the name see Harduf, Biblical Names, 15.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 46:21. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 15. The word אחא means brother in Aaramaic. On family members as names see Introduction 1.5.1. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 11:29. אחיה was a prophet.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 21:19.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 17:1. Elijah was the name of a prophet. The name does not seem to have been in use for Jews, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. Note that this person is a Samaritan.

Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:22. This is a Second Temple name, since it is mentioned for more than one person, but only in Second Temple compositions (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). It is also mentioned in Persian-dominated Egypt (TADAE4, no. 21.3).
Biblical priestly course: 1 Chr 24:12, see Introduction 1.1.1.3.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 19:16. אלישע was a prophet, and Elijah’s disciple, see Introduction 1.1.1.1.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 24:8.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:23. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction, 1.1.1.2.
Biblical, Jerem 29:3.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 48:5. אפרים was Joseph’s son and one of the tribes of Israel.

Biblical, e.g. Ezra 8:11. The name is probably Aramaic, since it is only documented in post-exilic books of the Bible (Ezra, Neh). See also Lipiński, Studies 1, 111. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.3.
Biblical priestly course, 1 Chr 24:14, see Introduction 1.1.1.3.
Biblical, 1 Kgs 4:13. Also on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 333. The name גברא is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 81).
Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 11:22. בניה is one of King David’s generals.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 35:18. בנימין is Jacob’s youngest son and one of the tribes of Israel, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 34.

Biblical, e.g. Neh 7:52. The name is only documented in post-exilic books of the Bible (Ezra, Neh). It is also documented on Hebrew First Temple seals (CWSSSnos. 110, 424). בסא is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 77).
Biblical, e.g. Jerem 32:12. ברוך was Jeremiah’s scribe.
Biblical, 1 Sam 17:4. גלית was the Philistine giant that David overcame in battle.
Biblical, e.g. Num 1:10. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 42.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 21:8. דואג was David’s Edomite enemy. For rabbinic etymology of the name see Harduf, Biblical Names, 45.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 16:13. דוד was the name of the famous king of Israel. It was seldom used as a personal name, see Introduction 1.1.1.1.
Biblical priestly course, 1 Chr 24:18, see Introduction 1.1.1.3.
Biblical, e.g. Dan 1:7. דניאל is the biblical figure who gave his name to the book of Daniel.
Biblical, e.g. Hos 1:1. הושע is the prophet who gave his name to the book of Hosea.

Biblical, e.g. Judg 12:13. In the case of Hillel, the relative popularity of the name in the latter documents found in this list may be the result of the popularity of Hillel the Elder and his activities in Palestine. See particularly Hillel no. 4.
Biblical priestly course, 1 Chr 24:10, see Introduction 1.1.1.3.

Biblical, Ezra 10:36. So too DJD 2, 223. Noth, IPRGN, 64, has suggested that this is a Persian name. Wan(a) is an element that repets itself in Persian names and means “victorious” (Justi, NB, 347). See also Cohen, Lĕšonénu31 (1967) 100, n. 9; JSJ 7 (1976) 111; JSJ 15 (1984) 57, n. 71.

Biblical, 1 Chr 8:17. During the Greco-Roman period forms of this name became popular among other Semitic peoples and it was not specifically identified with the Jews. Various forms of the name are recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 85-6); and in Idumaea (AOFCI, 99). For its Nabatean and Egyptian variations see below, n. 11.
Biblical, Neh 3:20. The name is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 86).
Biblical, 1 Chr 2:33. The name זוזי is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 86).
Biblical, e.g. Zech 1:1. זכריה is the prophet who gave the name to the biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 16:9. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 55. The name is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 86).
Biblical, Neh 7:48. חגב is recorded on First Temple Hebrew seals (CWSSS nos. 490-1).
Biblical, e.g. Hagai 1:12. חגי was the post-exilic prophet who gave the name to a biblical book. For rabbinic etymology of the name see Harduf, Biblical Names, 58.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:15. Note that the name is assigned to the son of Ishmael. It is probably of Arab provenance. Negev, Qedem 32, nos. 417 and 418, records the forms חדדו and חדודת, perhaps confirming this assumption. The names חדודן and חדידו are recorded in Palmyra. Stark, PNPI, 88, claims that the namederives from the Arabic “Sharp.” However, this name is close etymologically (and epigraphically) to הדד, the Aramaic godhead. On this name see G. Ryckmans, Les noms propres sud-sémitiques (Louvain 1934) 71-2.

Biblical, e.g. Exod 31:2. The name may be of Egyptian provenance, associated with the Egyptian deity Horus. It is certainly documented in Aramaic documents from Egypt in the Persian period, (TADAE 2, nos. 1.1, 3.7, 10, 11 [same person]; 3, nos. 3.15 [x2; חורי], 4.6 [חורי]; 4, nos. 5.35, 8.7, 9, 22.12 (חורי), 8.11, 18.17, 20.3, 22.18.
Biblical priestly course, 1 Chr 24:15, see Introduction 1.1.1.3. Names with the element חזיר (=חזירא, חזירו) are recorded in Idumaea (AOFCI, nos. 88, 174, 182).
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 18:1. חזקיה was king of Judah. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 60.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 1:1 (Nehemiah’s father).
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 18:37.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 5:23. This is the name of the almost mythical forefather of Noah who is supposed to have never died (on Enochic literature in the Second Temple period, see J. Greenfield, “Prolegomena,” in H. Odeberg [ed.], 3 Enoch or the Hebrew Book of Enoch [New York 1973] xvi-xxiii). The name was certainly not in common use. In any case, it is instructive to note that the name is given here as a father’s (i.e. family) name rather than a private one. Furthermore, the one person who bears this name is mentioned as a decoy for someone else, who was famous for having been excommunicated by the rabbis, because they wished to preserve the name of the latter. Thus אלעזר בן חנוך probably never existed. Still, it is instructive to note that the person he is supposed to supersede is called עקביה בן מהללאל. The second (father’s) name is also unique. It is noteworthy that In the Bible מהללאל was חנוך’s grandfather (Gen 5:12-7).
Biblical, e.g. Jerem 32:7.

Biblical, e.g. Jerem 35:4. This name has such an independent standing that one often loses sight of the fact that it is probably an abbreviation of חנניה, see Introduction 2.6.2. Because this distinction is already biblical, I have not listed the two names under a single heading here.
Biblical, e.g. Jerem 31:38.
Biblical, e.g. Jerem 28:1.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 46:12.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:52. The name is probably Aramaic, since it is only documented in post-exilic books of the Bible (Ezra, Neh).
Biblical, e.g. Neh 3:11. See Introduction 2.6.4.

Biblical, e.g. Zech 6:10. The most famous Τωβίας of Second Temple times are the heroes of the apocryphal book Tobit and his father, Τωβίθ. However, since the book is clearly fictitious, and refers to a time before the Hellenistic conquest, he is not included in this corpus, even if the book itself was composed in the Hellenistic period.
Biblical, e.g. Jerem 35:3.
Biblical, e.g. Num 32:41. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 66.
Biblical, e.g. Zech 6:10. The longer form – יאשיהו – is the name of a king of Judah (2 Kgs 21:26). For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 66.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 10:22. This name only appears in the Second Temple biblical book Neh. It is obviously an abbreviated form of ידעיה, see Introduction 2.6.4.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 19:16. יהוא was a king of Israel.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:35. יהודה was one of Jacob’s sons, and a tribe of Israel, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 67-8. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.
Biblical priestly course, 1 Chr 24:7, see Introduction 1.1.1.3.
Biblical, e.g. Hagai 1:1.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 22:51. יהורם was a name of a king of Judah.

Biblical, e.g. Exod 17:9. יהושע was the name of the general, Moses’ successor, who gave his name to a biblical book, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 71-2.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 26:6. יואב was David’s chief of staff. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 72.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 14:1. יואחז was king of Israel, elsewhere known as יהואחז.
Biblical, e.g. Jerem 40:16. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.
Biblical, 2 Kgs 14:25. יונה was the prophet after whom a biblical book is called.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 13:2. Jonathan was King Saul’s son, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:24. יוסף was a son of Jacob, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. The name is as popular as the Hasmonean names, see Introduction 1.1.1.2. On the suggestion that it was also a name of a Hasmonean brother, see below, n. 20.
Biblical, 1 Chr 12:7. J. Grinz, “Jehoezer: Unknown High Priest?” JQR 50 (1959-60), 338-45, suggested that יועזר was a priestly names, but the biblical יועזר is not a priest.
Biblical, e.g. Ezek 1:3. יחזקאל was a prophet who gave his name to a biblical book.
Biblical priestly course, 1 Chr 24:17, see Introduction 1.1.1.3.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:26. יעקב is the third Patriarch, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 75-6.
Biblical, e.g. Num 13:7. יפנה was the father of Caleb, who was sent by Moses as a spy.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 17:19. יצחק is the second Patriarch, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 78.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 8:19.
Biblical, e.g. Jerem 27:1. ירמיה was the prophet who gave his name to the biblical book. For rabbinic etymology of the name see Harduf, Biblical Names, 81.
Biblical priestly course: 1 Chr 24:13, see Introduction 1.1.1.3. See also Stern, “Aspects of Jewish Society,” 591.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 16:11. The biblical Ishmael, the first-born, rejected son of Abraham could not have been a likely role model for name giving. Nevertheless, it was very popular in Second Temple times, and seems to have already been in use among Jews toward the close of the First Temple Period (2 Kgs 25:25) and see also Introduction 1.1.1.1. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 83.
Biblical, e.g. Ezr 8:7. ישעיהו was the prophet who gave his name to the biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:18. יששכר was a son of Jacob, and one of the tribes of Israel. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 84-5.

Biblical, 2 Sam 17:25. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 85-6. In 2 Sam 17:25 יתרא is described as יתרא הישראלי, but in 1 Chr 2:17 the same person is described as יתר הישמעאלי, i.e. an Arab, and this makes more sense and is probably the original version, for why would an Israelite be thus described in an all Israelite composition? The name continued to be in use among Arabs (Nabateans -Negev, Qedem32, no. 546).
Biblical, Jerem 36:14. Also on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 339. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 88.
Biblical, e.g. Num 13:6. Caleb was one of the spies Moses sent to inspect Canaan.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:34. לוי was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 96. A relevant question is whetherall persons named Levi in this period wereLevites? On this, see Stern, “Aspects of Jewish Society,” 599.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 5:12. This is the name of one of the forefather of Noah. The name was certainly not in common use. In any case, it is instructive to note that the name is given as a father’s (i.e. family) name rather than a private one. See also under Enoch.
Biblical, e.g. Mi 1:1. מיכה is the biblical prophet who gave his name to a book.
Biblical, 1 Chr 8:9.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 15:14. Menahem was the one beforelast king of Israel, see Introduction 1.1.1.1.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 41:51. מנשה is Joseph’s son and one of the tribes of Israel, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 104.
Biblical, see Neh 10:9.
Biblical, e.g. Esth 2:1. מרדכי was Queen Esther’s uncle.

Biblical, e.g. Exod 2:10. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 109. The name of Moses the Lawgiver was not in use among Jews during the Second Temple period, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. The inscription published by Conder, PEFQS 17 (1883) 172, as reading אלעזר בר משה was later examined by Clermont-Ganneau Researches 2, 286, who read חנניה בר אלעזר. The text here could probably also be read otherwise.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 22:3. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 109.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 24:17.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:43. This name is only documented in post-exilic biblical books (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). This is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.
Biblical, Gen 25:13. In the Bible this name is used for the son of Ishmael, suggesting it may be of Arabic origin.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:23. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 113.
Biblical, 1 Chr 3:18.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 8:33. In the Bible the name is feminine. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 113-4.

Biblical, e.g. Nah 1:1. נחום was the prophet who gave his name to a biblical book. According to Noth, IPRGN, 38, נחום is a variation of נחמיה, see Introduction 2.6.4. However, because the Bible distinguishes clearly between the two, they are listed here under two separate entries.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 1:1. נחמיה was the Jewish leader who gave his name to a historical biblical book.
Biblical, Neh 7:7.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:8. נפתלי was one of Jacob’s twelve sons and a tribe of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Jerem 32:12. Neriyah was the name of Baruch, Jeremiah’s scribe’s father.

Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 7:2. נתן was the name of David’s prophet. Because this is such an independent biblical name, one loses sight of the fact that it is in fact an abbreviation of a name such as יונתן or נתנאל, see Introduction 2.6.2. Because of its biblical independent nature, it is listed here under an independent heading.
Biblical, e.g. Num 1:8. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 119-20.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 6:29. The names עבדא / עבדי are recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 102).
In the Bible the name is documented as עזיאל, e.g. Exod 6:22. As עזאל it is documented on an Amonite First Temple seal (CWSSS no. 355).
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 7:1. עזרא is the scribe who gave his name to a biblical book. This is clearly an abbreviated form of עזריה, see Introduction 2.4.2.5.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 14:21. עזריה was a king of Judah.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 1:3. עלי was the priest who brought up Samuel.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:18. עמרם was Moses’ father. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 135.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:45. Obviously here the Bible preserves the abbreviated form of the non-biblical עקביה, see Introduction 2.6.4.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 23:26.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 22:12.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 23:36.
Biblical, e.g. Neh 10:23.
Biblical, 1 Chr 3:24.
Biblical, Neh 11:12.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 4:4. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 146-7.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:25. פנחס was the name of Aaron’s grandson. In the Bible the name is spelled as a rule פינחס.
Biblical, Neh 7:57.
Biblical, Num 34:25. This is most likely a Persian name (Φαρνάκης-Phaŗnak, Justi, INB, 92-3). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.5.2.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:23.
Biblical, 1 Chr 8:9.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 15:24. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 152.
Biblical, e.g. Jerem 27:12. צדקיה was the last king of Judah. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 152-3.
Biblical, e.g. Zeph 1;1. צפניה was the biblical prophet who gave his name to a book.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:32. ראובן was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 163.
Biblical, Gen 36:13.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 9:2. שאול was the first king of Israel, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 167.

Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:42. Probably a hypocoristic of a name such as שבניה, see Introduction 2.4.1.3. For rabbinic etymology of the name see Harduf, Biblical Names, 168. The names שבא / שבי are recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 113).
Biblical, e.g. Isa 22:15.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:15.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 46:16. For rabbinic etymology of the name see Harduf, Biblical Names, 170.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 8:3.
Biblical, e.g. Jerem 37:3.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 6:1. שם was the name of Noah’s son.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 1:20. שמואל was the prophet who gave his name to two biblical books, see Introduction 1.1.1.1.
Biblical, e.g. Num 13:4. This name belongs to the family of the name שמעיה, see Introduction 2.6.4.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 36:36. שמלה was one of the ancient kings of Edom.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:33. שמעון was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel, see Introduction 1.1.1.1. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 176. This was the most popular name for Jewish Palestinian males in this period (C. Roth, “Simon-Peter,” HTR 54 [1961] 91-7). Note also, that this is a Hasmonean name, see Introduction 1.1.1.2.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 12:22. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 176.
Biblical, Jerem 39:3. This is a Babylonian name.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 4:25. For rabbinic etymology of the name, see Harduf, Biblical Names, 182.
Biblical, 1 Chr 4:12.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:15. The name is associated with a son of Ishmael – i.e. it may be of Arab extraction. The name תימא is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 117).
